loans.name: Obenda

texts.en:
Obenda is 39 years old.  She is married and has 2 children.   Obenda works hard to provide for her family. She has been running a sari-sari store in the Philippines for the last 7 years.  She also earns extra income from raising livestock and farming rice.

Obenda has requested a PHP 15000 loan through NWTF to buy more stocks to sell in her sari-sari store.  She has successfully repaid 3 previous loans from NWTF.   Obenda aspires to build and expand her business to secure the future for her family.

loans.use: buy more stocks for her store

loans.name: Vilma

texts.en:
Vilma is 34 years old, married and has 3 children.   Vilma works hard to provide for her family. She has been running a ari-sari store in the Philippines for the past 3 years.  She also earns extra income from food vending. 

Vilma has requested a 10000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy items to sell in her sari-sari store such as bread, groceries products, etc.   She has  successfully repaid 1 previous loan from NWTF before this loan.   Vilma aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: buy items to sell

loans.name: Mabasa Makuru Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Zimbabwe! This is 47-year-old Olivia (with the white bandana) from Mutare. She is married and has four children, one is currently attending school.  Olivia runs a cross-border retail business selling clothing and blankets.  Her business has been in operation for 3 years and she employs one other person. She says that the main challenge she faces is lack of working capital. 

Olivia has requested a loan of $400 to boost her stocks. She says the extra income generated as a result of this loan will allow her to improve her family's lifestyle. In the future, Olivia plans to grow her business into a shop.

loans.use: to increase her stocks

loans.name: Ma. Christine Mae

texts.en:
Ma. Christine Mae is 27 years old.  She is married and has 1 child. She is a very hard working entrepreneur.  She has a food vending business in the Philippines and has running it for 2 years.

Ma. Christine Mae has requested a PHP 11,000 loan through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food production business.   In the future, she would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: buy ingredients for her food vending business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Remedios

texts.en:
Remedios is 57 years old.  She is married and has six children.  She works hard to provide for her family.  Remedios runs a general store in the Philippines and has been running this business for 3 years.  She also earns extra income from a tricycle transport business.

Remedios has requested a PHP 20,000 loan through NWTF to buy more stocks to sell in her store.  She has successfully repaid 5 previous loans from NWTF before this loan.   Remedios aspires to save enough money to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: buy more stock to sell in her store

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is 36 years old and married with one child who is 8 years old and three relatives to care for. Grace sells children`s cloths and elder`s cloths in the market. 

Grace has two year's experience. Her business day is from 7 am to 6 pm every day but Saturday. Grace has requested a loan from Kiva in order to purchase more second-hand clothes. With the additional profits from this business, Grace will be able to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: To purchase more second-hand clothes to sell

loans.name: Concepcion

texts.en:
Concepcion is 42 years old.  She is married and has 8 children, 4 of whom are in school.    Concepcion is in the agricultural business raising pigs in the Philippines.   She has been in this business for 8 years.  

Concepcion has requested a PHP 18,000 loan through NWTF to buy feeds and vitamins for her pigs.  She has successfully repaid 13 previous loans in the past from NWTF, loans taken out to sustain her business.  In the future, she would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: buy feeds and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Maria

texts.en: Maria, 53-year-old married mother of six children, has been.raising livestock in the Philippines for three years now. Having already borrowed and repaid 15 loans in the past from NWTF, she is now requesting a PHP 16,000 loan to buy additional livestock. In the future, Maria would like to repair and renovate her family home.

loans.use: to buy additional livestock.

loans.name: Mumtaz's Group

texts.en:
Mumtaz is 45 years old and has given birth to five sons. Three of them work as salesmen and the other two are enrolled in a local school and getting their education. 

Mumtaz is a very active and supportive lady. She sells bangles to different cosmetics shops. Her business is well established and the income she earns helps her pay the school fee of her children. Besides her business, she also manages her household responsibilities very well. Her husband operates a food stall business. He is known for the good taste and his good customer service. 

Mumtaz has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan, he will buy ingredients such as chickpeas, cooking oil and spices etc. required for making food to sell and earn better profits. He has been operating this business for the past 25 years and is hopeful that a loan will be even more profitable for him.

loans.use: To buy ingredients required to make food to sell

loans.name: Perlita

texts.en: Perlita, 56 years old, is married with 8 children, one of whom attends school. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. Perlita has operated a cake and pastries business in the Philippines for 10 years. She has requested a PHP 29,000 loan through NWTF to buy ingredients for her baking business. In the future, Perlita would like to build and expand her business to secure her family's future.

loans.use: To buy ingredients for her baking business.

loans.name: Ellen

texts.en:
As a married parent of 2 children, Ellen works hard to support her family. She has a ready-to-wear clothing and personal collections business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from raising pigs. Ellen is borrowing PHP 12,000 through NWTF to purchase additional stock for her business.

Ellen has been sustaining her business activities through her past 2 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money to afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock to sell.

loans.name: Ma. Erma

texts.en: Ma. Erma is single and she works hard to support her family. She has operated a furniture making business in the Philippines for 5 years. Ma. Erma has requested a PHP 25,000 loan through NWTF to buy materials for her business. In the future, Ma. Erma would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy materials for her business.

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn is a hardworking entrepreneur who has operated a pig fattening business in the Philippines for 10 years. She is borrowing PHP 15,000 through NWTF to purchase feed and vitamins for her pigs. Marilyn earns additional income from buying and selling firewood and bananas.

Marilyn has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of loans from NWTF. She dreams of building and expanding her business to secure her family's future.

loans.use: To purchase feed and vitamins for her pigs.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Marites is 29 years old and married with 4 children. She works hard to provide for her family. Marites has operated a sari-sari (variety) store in the Philippines for 7 years. She has requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional items such as sardines, sugar, etc. to sell in her store.

Marites has previously borrowed and repaid 9 loans from NWTF. She also earns an income from buying and selling squid. Marites hopes to save enough money to buy a bigger fishing boat.

loans.use: To buy additional items to sell.

loans.name: Jekadi 1 Group

texts.fr:
Les 10 membres du groupe JEKADI 1 sont toutes mariées et vivent à Kapala, dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies avec leurs enfants, maris, beaux-parents, belles-sœurs  etc. Elles ont en moyenne 31 ans, au moins 5 enfants. Le village est un chef lieu de commune situé à environ 17 km  de la ville de Sikasso troisième  région administrative de la république du Mali.  
Elles exercent la culture du pois sucré, (tels avec KIA) ce produit est très  prisé actuellement par des industriels de la région qui  font sa transformation en jus. 
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leur activité agricole, les membres du groupe ont donc décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso cette année. Elles sont à leur premier cycle de prêt de campagne. Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter,  une quantité suffisante de semence de pois, des intrants et des équipements appropriés pour sa production et sa récolte. Ces équipements et intrants seront achetés au grand marché de Sikasso. Après les récoltes en fin de campagne, les produits sont stockés pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendus  au grand marché de la ville de Sikasso en détail et en gros , à divers client.
 KIA compte utiliser personnellement  son prêt  de la façon suivante achat, d’un sac d’urée, de  2 sacs de complexe céréale et le reste comme frais de labour et de sarclage. 
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 60.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The ten members of the Jekadi group are all married and live in Kapala in large traditional families with their children, husbands, parents- and sisters-in-law etc. They are all around 31 years old with an average of 5 children each. The village is the capital of the municipality and is around 17km away from Sikasso, the third largest administrative region in the Republic of Mali. The members, such as Kia, cultivate sweet-peas; these are highly sought-after by producers in the region who press them for juice. 
In order to generate greater profits from their agricultural activities, the group members have decided to seek assistance from the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance programme this year. They are on their first loan cycle, which will be used to purchase a sufficient quantity of pea seeds, agricultural products and tools required for the pea production and harvesting process. These materials will be purchased from the large market at Sikasso. After harvesting the crops at the end of the season, the products are stocked for a certain amount of time so that they may accrue in value before being sold at the large market of Sikasso for cash and credit sales to a varied customer base. 
Kia aims to use her loan in order to purchase a bag of nitrogen powder, two bags of complex cereals and the rest will be used to pay labour and hoeing costs. 
She aims to generate an average monthly profit of 60,000 FCFA which will be used to repay the loan and to meet her family's everyday requirements.

loans.use: to purchase agricultural products and to pay for labour

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to boost his business by buying more stocks of male and female clothing for sale

loans.name: Mwanaisha

texts.en:
Mwanaisha is 36 years old and married to Ali. She has rental houses as her primary business and sells new bags, clothes and shoes as her secondary business. She has been in business for the last six years, earning a monthly profit of KES 28,000.

Mwanaisha was introduced to KADET LTD by an existing customer and this will be her second loan. She plans to use it to renovate her rental houses and to increase her stock of shoes, handbags and clothes for sale. From her anticipated profits, Mwanaisha plans to put up more rental houses. In the future, Mwanaisha hopes to be a landlady with over one hundred rental units. She is a very hardworking woman.

loans.use: to renovate her rental houses and to increase her stock of shoes, handbags and clothes for sale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy jeans, ladies' belts and ladies' suits.

loans.name: Elisol

texts.en:
Elisol is a hardworking entrepreneur who has operated a food vending business, selling chicharon (fried pork rinds) in the Philippines for 10 years. She is borrowing PHP 15,000 through NWTF to purchase ingredients such as pork skin and spices for her business. Elisol earns additional income from selling ready-to-wear clothes and frozen products.

Elisol has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of loans from NWTF. She dreams to save enough to build a house for her family in the future.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock of ingredients.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to add to his stock of ladies' clothes.

loans.name: Editha

texts.en:
Editha is 42 years old and married with six children. She works hard to provide for her family. Editha has operated a sari-sari (variety) store in the Philippines for two years. She has requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more goods such as soap, detergent and soft drinks to sell in her store.

Editha has previously borrowed and repaid 3 loans from NWTF. She also earns an income from raising livestock. Editha hopes to save enough money to continue sending her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase more goods such as soap, detergent and soft drinks to sell in her store.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Petra

texts.en:
Petra is a 26 years old single woman, owner of a cake factory since January 2010. She has 13 years of experience. Petra started working early in this business when she was only 13 years old. She started working in order to help her parents in their daily living needs.

Petra worked hard to improve herself, especially when she insisted on making her own business, with the small capital she had. Hopefully she has reached a good level now and she's intending, through a loan requested from Al Majmoua-Kiva partner, to buy a new ice cream and frisco machine (smoothie machine). 

A Smothie (alternatively, spelled smoothy) is a blended, chilled, sometimes sweetened, beverage made from fresh fruit (fruit smoothie) or vegetables and, in special cases, can contain chocolate. In addition to fruit, many smoothies include crushed ice, frozen fruit, honey or contain syrup and ice ingredients. They have a milkshake-like consistency that is thicker than slush drinks. They can also contain milk or yogurt and a small number of smoothies do use ice cream. Smoothies are often marketed to health-conscious people, and some restaurants offer add-ins such as soy milk, whey powder, green tea, herbal supplements, or nutritional supplement mixes. Smoothies became widely available in the United States in the late 1960s when ice cream vendors and health food stores began selling them. By the 1990s and 2000s, smoothies became available at mainstream cafés and coffee shops and in pre-bottled versions at supermarkets all over the world.)

These machines will help increase her income, especially in the upcoming summer season. Petra hopes to expand her business more and more and support every department in a special way to make all of them develop equally.

loans.use: to buy new frisco-smoothie and ice cream machines.

loans.name: Joyce Wambui

texts.en:
Joyce Wambui is 44 years old. She is married to David, who contributes to the family income. She has three children, 20, 17 and 10 years of age. She does dairy farming and grows tea. She has been in the agriculture business for a period of about six years, with an income of 18,000 per month.

This is her second loan with the KADET LTD, after repaying the previous one successfully. She wants the loan to buy fish feed and daily feed and also to buy farm inputs.

She hopes to own a big farm and to improve the living standard of her family.

loans.use: to buy fish feed and daily feed and also buy farm inputs.

loans.name: Mean

texts.en: Mean, 46, is a humble villager. She and her husband work in the farming business. The couple has been growing crops for years. They earn an average of $3 per day. The couple has two children, each employed as a worker in the tobacco factory and getting a specific salary. For extra-profit, Mean has requested for a loan to purchase a piece of land which has its location under her house. With this land, she can plant her rice crops business or expand her house.

loans.use: to purchase a piece of land.

loans.name: Mutava

texts.en:
Mutava is married and has five children. He operates a cafeteria to earn a living for his family. It has been eleven years since he started the business.  

Mutava has employed two people to assist him in his business. He is a hardworking man who hopes to improve his business and become financially stable in five years. He has requested for his first loan from Faulu Kenya. With 20,000 KES, he will buy maize flour, charcoal, cooking fat and sugar.

loans.use: to buy maize flour, charcoal, cooking fat and sugar.

loans.name: Riza

texts.en:
Riza is 46 years old. She is married and has 3 children.

Riza works hard to provide for her family. She runs a sari-sari store in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 14,500 loan through NWTF. She would like to use the loan to buy items to sell, like shampoo, groceries, etc., in her sari-sari store.

Riza has borrowed and repaid 15 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the sari-sari store for 12 years and also earns an income from food vending.

Riza aspires to build and expand her business in order to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy items to sell in her sari-sari store.

loans.name: Daniela

texts.en:
Daniela is 43 years old and married with nine children.

Daniela works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 12,000 loan through NWTF to buy more stock to sell to customers.

Daniela has borrowed and paid back four loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for two years and earns additional income from food vending.

Daniela aspires to save enough to build a piggery for the expansion of her business.

loans.use: to buy more stock to sell to customers

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Jekadi Ii Group

texts.fr:
Les 10 membres du groupe JEKADI II sont des femmes toutes mariées, vivant à Kapala, dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies. Elles ont en moyenne 31 ans, au moins 5 enfants. Le village est un chef lieu de commune situé à environ 17 km  de la ville de Sikasso troisième  région administrative de la république du Mali.  
Elles exercent la culture du pois de terre. 
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leur activité agricole, les membres du groupe ont donc décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso cette année. Elles sont à leurs premiers cycles de prêt de campagne. 
SALI compte utiliser son prêt de façon suivante: achat d’un sac d’urée, 2 sacs de complexe et le reste comme frais de labour et de sarclage. Ces équipements et intrants seront achetés au grand marché de Sikasso. Après les récoltes en fin de campagne, les produits sont stockés pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de la ville de Sikasso en détail (souvent en gros) à divers client..
 Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 50.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The 10 members of the Jekadi II group are married woman who all live in Kapala in large, traditional extended families. They are 31 years old, and have an average of at least 5 children each. The village is a regional capital and is around 17km from Sikasso, the third largest administrative region of the Republic of Mali. They cultivate peas for a living. 
In order to generate greater profits from their agricultural activities, the members of the group are seeking funding from the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance programme.  They are on the first loan cycle. 
One of the group members, Sali, aims to use her loan in order to purchase nitrogen powder and two bags of soil complex; the rest will be used to pay labour and hoeing costs. These tools and materials will be purchased from the large market at Sikasso. Following their harvest, the products are stocked for a certain length of time in order to accrue in value before being sold at the large market of Sikasso for retail or wholesale sales to a varied customer base. Sali aims to generate an average monthly profit of 50,000 FCFA which will be used to pay back the loan and the family's everyday expenditure.

loans.use: to purchase agricultural ingredients and to pay labour costs

loans.name: Alejandra

texts.en:
Alejandra is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a business buying and selling vegetables in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 10,000 through NWTF to purchase more stock of vegetable to sell.

Alejandra has been in this business for three years. Alejandra earns additional income from farming vegetables.

Alejandra has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of saving money to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: To purchase more vegetables to sell

loans.name: Bayana Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité est créé le 19 octobre 2001. Il est  constitué de cinq femmes qui habitent le même quartier. Leur activité principale est le petit commerce.

Madame Khady qui est à la droite de la photo levant la main et le responsable de groupe. Elle est âgée de 55 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de sept enfants. Elle a aussi en sa charge quatre autre enfants confié par ses parents.

Elle s’active dans la vente de savon et de bouillie de mil. Elle a une bonne expérience dans ce domaine d’activité, car étant pratiquer depuis plusieurs années.

Ce prêt lui permettra de renforcer son capital et de mieux développer  ses activités.

Les profits lui permettront d’améliorer les conditions de vie de la famille (santé, nourriture, habillement etc.…) et d’augmenter ses épargnes.
texts.en:
This solidarity group was formed on the 19th of October, 2001. It is made up of five women who live in the same quarter and who run small businesses. 

Madame Khady - who is on the right of the photo with her hand raised - is the group's leader. She is 55 years old, married, and has seven children. She also looks after four children whose parents gave her guardianship over them. 

She sells soap and millet broth for a living, a field in which she has considerable experience after several years' worth of work. 

This loan will enable her to boost her working capital and to better develop her business. 

The profits that she generates will enable her to see to her family's living conditions (health, food, clothing etc), and to boost her savings.

loans.use: to purchase soap and millet

loans.name: Venant

texts.en: Venant is 42 years old and is married with seven children, who are between 2 and 15 years old. He sells boutique items (sugar, salt, rice, maize, etc.) He has 12 years of experience and he employs one person to help him. He works from 6 am until 10 pm every day. Venant has requested his first loan from Kiva partner Vision Finance Company in order to purchase more cooking oil, beans, sorghum, sugar, salt, rice, maize and so on. With these profits, Venant will reinvest in his business and pay his children's school fees.

loans.use: to purchase more sugar, salt, rice, maize and so on.

loans.name: Annabell

texts.en:
Annabell is 35 years old and married with two children.

Annabell works hard to provide for her family. She runs a sari-sari store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 12,000 loan through NWTF to buy items to sell like shampoo, groceries, etc. in her sari-sari store.

Annabell has borrowed and paid five loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the sari-sari store for 10 years and earns additional income from food vending.

Annabell aspires to save enough money to send her children to college.

loans.use: To buy items to sell in her sari-sari store

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Consolacion

texts.en:
Consolacion is 33 years old and married with three children.

Consolacion works hard to provide for her family. She runs a sari-sari store in the Philippines and is requesting a PHP 24,000 loan through NWTF to buy grocery items such as noodles, canned goods, soap and other products to sell in her sari-sari store.

Consolacion has borrowed and paid back 14 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the sari-sari store for four years and earns additional income from buying and selling copra.

Consolacion aspires to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: To buy items such as noodles, canned goods, soap and other products to sell in her sari-sari store

loans.name: Madya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité est créé le 19 octobre 2001. Il est composé de neuf femmes qui habitent le même quartier. Leur activité principale est le petit commerce.

Madame Gnima qui est à la droite de la photo levant la main est responsable de groupe. Elle est âgée de 40 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de six enfants.

Elle s’active dans la vente d'huile de palme. Elle a une bonne expérience dans ce domaine d’activité pour l'avoir pratiquer depuis plusieurs années.

Ce prêt lui permettra de renforcer son capital et de mieux développer  ses activités.

Les profits lui permettront d’améliorer les conditions de vie de la famille (santé, nourriture, habillement etc.…) et d’augmenter ses épargnes.
texts.en:
This solidarity group was formed on the 19th of October, 2001. It is made up of nine women who all live in the same quarter and run small businesses. 

Madame Gnima - who is on the right of the photo with her hand raised - is the group's leader. She is 40 years old, married, and a mother of six children. 

She sells palm oil for a living, and has worked in this field for several years. 

This loan will enable her to boost her working capital and to develop her business further. 

The profits that she generates will enable her to see to her family's needs (health, food, clothing etc) andn to boost her savings.

loans.use: to purchase palm oil

loans.name: Chan

texts.en: Mrs. Chan has been working in the farming business for a long time in Kompong Cham province. She has good skills planting different kinds of crops on her own land. Mrs. Chan and her husband assist each other in the farm field and make about $3 each day to cover their daily expenses. As she lacks immediate cash to begin to her rice crop, Mrs. Chan would like to request a Kiva loan to buy seeds, fertilizers and insecticides to protect her crops. She will use the remainder of the loan money to purchase some piglets to feed.

loans.use: to buy seeds, fertilizers, insecticides and piglets

loans.name: Afisa

texts.en:
Afisa is 56 year old and is married with three children between the ages 12 and 19 years old. She sells fruit and vegetables in the market. She has seven years of experience.

Afisa has requested a loan from Vision Finance Company in order to purchase more vegetables and fruit. With these profits, she will be able to save money in order to expand her business and to pay her children's school fees.

loans.use: to purchase more fruits and vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Jekadi Iii Group

texts.fr:
Les 10 femmes du groupe JEKADI III  sont toutes mariées et vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies avec leurs enfants, maris, beaux-parents, belles-sœurs etc, à KAPALA. Elles ont en moyenne 31 ans, au moins 5 enfants. Le village est un chef lieu de commune situé à environ 17 km  de la ville de Sikasso troisième  région administrative de la république du Mali.  
Elles font plusieurs culture telle celle du pois sucré avec FILAMOUSSO. Le pois sucré est très  prisé et consommé actuellement  avec les industriels de la région qui font sa transformation en jus et son exportation pour autres besoins. 
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs activités agricoles, les membres du groupe ont donc décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso cette année. Elles sont à leurs premiers cycles de prêt de campagne. FILAMOUSSO  compte acheter, 1 sac d’urée, 2 sacs de complexe et quelques petits matériels agricoles. Ces équipements et intrants seront achetés au grand marché de Sikasso. Après les récoltes en fin de campagne, les produits sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de la ville de Sikasso en détail (souvent en gros) à divers client.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 55.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The ten women in the Jekadi III group are all married and live in Kapala in large traditional extended families with their children, husbands, parents-in-laws, sisters-in-law etc. They are on average 31 years old with at least five children. The village is a township capital, located about 10 miles from the city of Sikasso, third administrative region of the Republic of Mali.
They grow several crops, such as tiger nuts for Filamousso. Tiger nuts are very popular and widely consumed at present, with regional manufacturers processing it into juice and exporting it for other needs.
In order to make their agricultural activities more profitable, the group members have decided to join Soro Yiriwaso's loan program this year. They are on their first rural loan cycles. Filamousso intends to purchase one bag of urea, two bags of fertilizer, and some small agricultural tools. This equipment and supplies will be purchased at Sikasso's great market. After the harvest at the end of the cycle, the products will be stored for a certain time to gain value before being sold at the great market of Sikasso city, to various retail or (often) wholesale clients.
She is planning on an average benefit of 55,000 CFA, which will be used to pay the loan's interests and the family's daily expenses.

loans.use: to buy agricultural supplies and small equipment.

loans.name: Esther Zighe

texts.en: Esther Zighe is a 32-year-old single mother supporting two children, 4 and 7 years old. She has been running a retail shop for about three years, earning a monthly income of KES 8,000. This is her second loan from KADET LTD, having repaid the previous one successfully. Esther Zighe will use the loan to buy sugar and cooking fat for her shop. She hopes to own a wholesale shop to provide for her children's education and improve their living standard.

loans.use: to buy sugar and cooking fat for her shop.

loans.name: Jekadi Iv Group

texts.fr:
Les 7 femmes du groupe JEKADI IV sont toutes mariées et vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies avec leurs enfants, maris, beaux-parents, belles-sœurs à KAPALA. Elles ont en moyenne 28 ans, au moins 3 enfants. Le village est un chef lieu de commune situé à environ 17 km  de la ville de Sikasso troisième  région administrative de la république du Mali.  
Elles font essentiellement la culture du pois sucré  avec WASSA..
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leur activité agricole, les membres du groupe ont donc décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso cette année. Elles sont à leurs premiers cycles de prêt de campagne. Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter,  une quantité suffisante de semence de pois, des intrants et des équipements appropriés pour sa production et sa récolte. WASSA compte acheter,  1 sac d’urée, 2 sacs de complexe. 
Ces équipements et intrants seront achetés au grand marché de Sikasso. Après les récoltes en fin de campagne, les produits sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de la ville de Sikasso en détail (souvent en gros) à divers client.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 55.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The seven women who make up the JEKADI IV group are all married and live in big traditional extended families with their children, husbands, parents-in-law, and sisters-in-law in KAPALA. They are on average 28 years old and have at least three children. The village is a county seat situated about 17 miles from the town of Sikasso, third administrative region of the Republic of Mali. They essentially grow sugar peas, as does for example WASSA. 

Wishing to make their agricultural activities profitable, the members of the group decided to join the loan program of Soro Yiriwaso this year. They are on their first seasonal loan. The loan itself will be used to buy a sufficient quantity of pea seeds, entrants, and appropriate equipment for their production and harvest. WASSA intends to buy one sack of urea and two sacks of a fertilizer complex. 

This equipment and these entrants are purchased at the big market in Sikasso. After the harvest at the end of the growing season, the products are stockpiled for a certain time so that their value rises before they are sold retail (often wholesale) at the big open-air market in Sikasso, to various customers. 

WASSA expects to make an average profit of 55,000 F CFA which will be used to reimburse the interest on the loan and to pay everyday expenses for her  family.

loans.use: to buy agricultural entrants.

loans.name: Jamal

texts.en:
Jamal is a 40-year-old married man, with no children yet to enjoy playing with, as he claims. Jamal has been painting furniture for 20 years, and his experience helps a lot in attracting customers from different regions requesting his service. His customers claim that Jamal's quality of work is excellent and he works hard to exactly fit his customers' requests.

Jamal is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua, Kiva's partner, in order to buy new updated tools for his business and to complete covering his newly built house's roof. This is Jamal's 12th cycle with Al Majmoua. His previous loans had a great impact on his business, which also improved his social situation. Al Majmoua is proud to deal with such a good standing borrower. He is a hard worker, self confident, and known for the excellent quality of work and the quick service he provides to his customers. Jamal hopes to expand his business and open his own furniture gallery in the future.

loans.use: To buy new updated tools for his business.

loans.name: Vincent

texts.en:
Vincent is 42 years old and is married with three children between the ages 11 and 21 years old. Vincent sells cooking oil, body lotion, soap and sugar. He has four years of experience and employs one person to help him.

Vincent has requested a loan from Kiva in order to purchase more salt, soap, sugar, cooking oil and body lotion. With these profits, Vincent will pay school fees for his children and save for his family.

loans.use: to purchase more salt, soap, sugar, cooking oil and body lotion.

loans.name: Mary Wambui

texts.en:
Mary Wambui is 65 years old and married to Josheph, a farmer who contributes to the family income. She has been rearing rabbits for 10 years, earning a monthly income of KES 9,000.

This is Mary Wambui's second loan from KADET LTD, having repaid the previous one successfully. She wants this loan to expand her rabbit pen and to buy more rabbit feed. She hopes to settle in rabbit keeping and improve her family's living standards.

loans.use: To buy rabbit feed and expand the rabbit pen.

loans.name: Kavata

texts.en:
Kavata aged 28 years old, is married to Fidelis and together they have two children. She has been running her beauty salon for seven years, earning a monthly income of KES 6,000. 

She is taking her second loan from KADET LTD after having successfully repaid the previous one. She will use this loan to buy more hair products and hair extensions. She hopes to educate her children and improve their living standard.

loans.use: To buy more hair products and hair extensions.

loans.name: Jekadi V Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe JEKADI V est un regroupement de sept femmes  qui sont toutes mariées et  qui vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies avec leurs enfants à KAPALA. Elles ont en moyenne 26 ans et au moins 4 enfants.
Elles font essentiellement  la culture du pois de terre depuis plusieurs années mais elles n’avaient jamais bénéficié d’un prêt pour leurs activités champêtres. 
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso. 
ASSETOU, compte utiliser son argent pour acheter, 1 sac d’urée, 2 sacs de complexe céréale et le reste comme frais de labour et de sarclage. 
Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché de Sikasso. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de Sikasso et à des clients possédant des unités de transformation de jus de pois de terre qui ne cessent d’augmenter. 
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 55.000 à 60 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille. 
NB : La nommée  AWA avait accouchée raison pour la quelle elle ne figure pas sur la photo.
texts.en:
The group called JEKADI V is made up of seven women who are all married and who live in big traditional extended families with their children in KAPALA. They are 26 years old on average and have at least four children. They have essentially grown Bambara peas (sugar peas) for several years but they have never received a loan for their agricultural endeavors. Wishing to make their farming profitable, the members of the group decided to join the loan program of Soro Yiriwaso. 
 
ASSETOU expects to use her loan money to buy one sack of urea and two sacks of cereal-complex fertilizer, using the rest of the loan to cover the cost of plowing and weeding. She buys her supplies at the big open-air market of Sikasso. 

At the end of the rainy season, the harvested crops are stockpiled for a certain time so that they gain in value before being sold at the big Sikasso marketplace to a growing number of customers who have equipment to make sugar pea juice. 

ASSETOU expects to make an average profit of 55,000 to 60,000 F CFA which will be used to pay the interest on the loan and to cover everyday family expenses. 

Note: The group member named AWA had just given birth and that is why she is not in the photo.

loans.use: to buy agricultural entrants and pay for plowing.

loans.name: Hoa

texts.en: Rice planting is the most popular business for people who live in the countryside. Mrs. Hoa is among those who earn an income from farming. She always uses her own fertile farm to grow many kinds of crops, according to the season. Her husband works alongside her in the field. They also depend on their two children; one is a businesswoman and one is employed as a factory worker in Phnom Penh City. Mrs. Hoa would like to ask for a loan of $800 to buy some bean oil to stock for future sale.

loans.use: to buy some bean oil to stock for future sale.

loans.name: Jean Marie Vianney

texts.en:
Jean Marie Vianney is 39 years old and is married with six children between the ages 3 and 13 years old. He sells chicken from 8 am until 9 pm every day. He has five years of experience in his business.

Jean Marie Vianney has requested a loan from Kiva in order to buy more chickens that will allow him to expand his business. With these profits, he will reinvest in his business and pay his children's school fees and support his family.

loans.use: to purchase more chicken to sell.

loans.name: Jekadi  A Group

texts.fr:
Les 10 femmes du groupe JEKADI A font partie de l’association JEKADI I de KAPALA. Elles sont toutes mariées et vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies avec leurs enfants, maris, beaux-parents, belles-sœurs  etc. Elles ont en moyenne 33 ans, au moins 4 enfants. KAPALA  de SIKASSO (troisième  région administrative de la république du Mali.)  
Elles font la culture du pois de terre et du pois sucré tels  avec TENIN.
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont donc décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso il y’a maintenant deux ans.
TENIN compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence de pois, des intrants et des équipements appropriés pour sa production et sa récolte. Ces équipements et intrants seront achetés au grand marché de Sikasso. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de la même ville en détail (souvent en gros) à divers clients.
TENIN envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 80.000 à 120 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The 10 women from the group called JEKADI A are members of the Association JEKADI I of KAPALA in SIKASSO (third administrative region of Mali). They are all married and live in big traditional extended families with their children, husbands, parents-in-law, sisters-in-law, etc. They are 33 years old on average and have at least four children. 

They grow Bambara and sugar peas, as does TENIN. Wishing to make their agricultural endeavors profitable, the members of the group decided to join the loan program of Soro Yiriwaso two years ago. 

TENIN intends to use her portion of the loan to buy a sufficient quantity of pea seeds, entrants, and appropriate equipment for cultivation and harvest. The equipment and entrants will be purchased at the big open-air market of Sikasso. After the rainy season is over, the harvest is stockpiled for a certain time so that its value increases before it is sold retail (often wholesale) at the big market of the same town to various customers. 

TENIN expects to make an average profit of 80,000 to 120,000 F CFA which will be used to reimburse the interest on the loan and for everyday family expenses.

loans.use: to buy seeds, entrants, and other agricultural supplies.

loans.name: Marie

texts.en:
Marie is a 50-year-old married woman with two children. Marie has worked as a tailor for 20 years and in 2009 she started her own business. Marie intended to do so because she was working hard to be independent and to provide a more comfortable life for her family.

Her sewing machines aren't modern and updated, but through a loan she's requesting from Kiva's partner, Al Majmoua, Marie will be capable of buying a special sewing machine in addition to a tailoring stand and necessary tailoring tools. These will definitely help in improving her quality and quantity of work.

Marie has been an Al Majmoua borrower for four consecutive cycles, and all of them reflected positively on her social and financial situation. She is also a good borrower that Al Majmoua is proud to deal with. Marie hopes to open her own atelier as soon as possible.

loans.use: To buy a special tailoring machine, a sewing stand and necessary sewing tools

loans.name: Jekadi  B Group

texts.fr:
Les 10 membres du groupe JEKADI  B sont toutes  des femmes mariées qui  vivent à KAPALA , dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies avec leurs enfants, maris, beaux-parents, belles-sœurs  etc. Elles ont en moyenne 30 ans, au moins 3 enfants. Le village est un chef lieu de commune situé à environ 17 km  de la ville de Sikasso troisième  région administrative de la république du Mali.  
Elles exercent comme  la plupart des femmes du Village de KAPALA, la culture du pois sucré, ce produit est très consommé actuellement par des industriels de la région qui font sa transformation en jus et son exportation. 
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs activité agricoles, les membres du groupe ont donc décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso il y’a maintenant deux ans. 
MADIALIA, la présidente du groupe, compte utiliser son prêt de la façon suivante: achat d’un sac d’urée, 2 sacs de complexe céréale et le reste comme frais de labour et de sarclage. Ces intrants seront achetés au grand marché de Sikasso. A la suite des récoltes en fin de campagne, les produits sont stockés pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendus  au grand marché de la même ville en détail (souvent en gros) à divers client.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 60.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The 10 members of the Jekadi B group are all married women who live in Kapala in large, traditional, and extended households with their children, husbands, in-laws, etc. They are on average 30 years old and each have at least 3 children. The town is an administrative centre situated about 17km from the city of Sikasso in the 3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali.
Like most of the women in the town of Kapala, these women farm tiger nuts, a product consumed in large quantities currently by regional industries, which convert it to juice and export it.
With the goal of making their farming businesses more profitable, the group members decided to join Soro Yiriwaso's loan program two years ago.
Madialia, the group president, intends to use her loan in the following manner: to buy one bag of urea and 2 bags of complex cereals, and to use the rest to pay for labour and hoeing. These inputs will be bought at the grand market in Sikasso. Following the harvest at the end of the season, the products are stored for a certain while so that they will be worth more when sold at the grand market in Sikasso and at retail (often in bulk) to various customers.
She foresees realizing an average profit of 60,000 FCFA, which will be used to pay the interest on the loan and to provide for her family's daily needs.

loans.use: To buy farming inputs and pay for labour costs.

loans.name: Syrgajan's Group

texts.en:
Syrgajan, 52, is the leader of this group. She resides in a town called Toktogul with a population of 19,000 people. She has a college-age daughter and a 17-year-old son. Syrgajan’s husband works in a hydroelectric station, while Syrgajan works hard breeding and selling cattle in order to make a living. Her business was started four years ago with the purchase of two heads of cattle for 8,000 soms. Currently her monthly income is 3,000 soms and it helped the family to get a small piece of land and increase the number of cattle they own. The purpose of the requested loan is to purchase more cattle for fattening and reselling. 

         --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Jekadi  C Group

texts.fr:
JEKADI C  est un regroupement de 10 femmes  du village de KAPALA. Elles vivent chez leurs mariées dans des grandes familles traditionnelles. Âgées d’au moins 34 ans elles possédant  en moyenne  4 enfants. Situé à environ 17 km de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali) le village de Kapala est aujourd’hui érigé  en un chef lieu de commune de la préfecture  de Sikasso. 
Les clientes exercent comme toutes les femmes du village et  la culture du pois sucré. 
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs activité agricoles, les membres du groupe ont  intégré  le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso il y’a maintenant deux ans. BINTOU pour l’exploitation de ses 2 hectares compte utiliser,  4 sacs d’urée  et le reste comme frais de labour et de sarclage. Ces intrants seront achetés au grand marché de Sikasso. A la suite des récoltes en fin de campagne, les produits sont stockés pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendus  au grand marché de la même ville en détail (souvent en gros) à divers client.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 40.000 à 45 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
Jekadi C is a group of 10 women from the town of Kapala. They live with their husbands in large traditional households. They are all at least 34 years old and have, on average, 4 children. Located 17 km from Sikasso (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali), the town of Kapala is currently set up as an administrative centre in the Sikasso prefecture.
Like all the women in the town of Kapala, these group members farm tiger nuts.
With the goal of making their farming activity more profitable, the group members joined Soro Yiriwaso's loan program two years ago. One of the group members, Bintou, intends to use her loan to farm 2 hectares of land by buying 4 bags of urea paying for labour and hoeing. These agricultural inputs will be bought at the grand market in Sikasso. Following the harvest at the end of the season, the products will be stocked for a certain while so that they will be worth more when sold at the grand market in Sikasso at retail (often in bulk) to various customers.
Bintou foresees realizing an average profit of 40,000 to 45,000 FCFA, which will be used to pay the interest on the loan and to provide for her family's ongoing needs.

loans.use: To buy agricultural inputs and to pay for labour.

loans.name: Bakbubu

texts.en:
Bakbubu, 42, is a resident of a coal mining town called Tashkomur. Bakbubu is a proud mother of five children, the youngest of whom is only four months old. In order to provide proper care for her toddler, she stays home while her husband works as a shepherd. However, she manages to run the business of livestock breeding along with her duties at home. Bakbubu feeds and waters her livestock, and afterwards her 22-year-old son takes the fattened livestock to a local farm for selling. She started doing this in the year 2000 and her long experience allows her to earn up to 20,000 soms per month. Bakbubu plans to expand her household by purchasing 4 more heads of livestock. She hopes the assistance of Kiva lenders will help her to do this. 

         --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase livestock

loans.name: Afiwa Enogandé

texts.fr: Femme dynamique de 48ans, Mme Afiwa est mariée à un ingénieur. Ils ont 05 enfants en charge et est à son premier prêt. Elle est revendeuse de gâteau (un aliment fait à base de farine de blé qui accompagne la bouillie). Elle a démarré l’activité depuis 1993 et sollicite ce prêt pour acheter de la farine de blé, de l’huile et du sucre au grand marché de Lomé pour satisfaire sa demande croissante, et participer à la charge de la famille.
texts.en: A dynamic 48-year-old woman, Ms. Afiwa is married to an engineer. They have 5 children in their care and she is on her first loan. She sells wheat cakes (a wheat flour-based food that accompanies the West African "bouillie" dish). She has run this business since 1993 and is seeking this loan to buy wheat flour, oil, and sugar at the grand market in Lomé in order to satisfy the increasing demand and to contribute to her family's care.

loans.use: To buy wheat flour, oil, and sugar.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Ali

texts.en: Ali is a 60-year-old married man who has worked hard painting cars for the past 35 years. He's an expert in his field, and most of his clients have been dealing with him for that long time. He is a hard working man who is requesting a loan from Kiva's partner, Al Majmoua, for the first time in order to buy necessary paints and tools for his business. Ali invests his good reputation in improving his business and expanding his working zone, and he hopes to stay healthy in order to meet his customers needs.

loans.use: To buy necessary paints and tools for his business

loans.name: Nurchakan

texts.en:
Nurchakan, 65, is a widow living in Southern Kyrgyzstan. In her teenage years, she showed early talent in sewing and designing clothing, skills she inherited from her mother. Now, she can perform a wide range of activities, from designing small souvenirs to making large hand-made carpets for home decoration.

Nurchakan resides in a small town called Tashkomur. Her daughters make it easier for her to run her business by supplying fabric from the capital. It was Nurchakan’s initiative to turn her home into a small fashion house. She has been in this industry for 31 years and her invested start-up capital of only 2,000 soms now brings 9,500 soms per month. Nurchakan has increased the goods circulation, obtained permanent clients and has a stable income. She believes these criteria will help her to repay the loan successfully. The purpose of the loan is to purchase fabric needed for the upcoming busy season.

         --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase fabric.

loans.name: Jekadi  D Group

texts.fr:
Les 10 membres du groupe JEKADI D  de KAPALA  sont des femmes toutes mariées et vivant dans des grandes familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 33 ans, au moins 4 enfants. KAPALA fait partie de  l’ex cercle de SIKASSO (troisième  région administrative de la république du Mali.)  
Elles exercent la culture du pois de terre.
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs activité agricoles, les membres du groupe ont  intégré le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso il y’a maintenant deux ans. CHATOU compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter 1 sac d’urée, 2 sacs de complexe et le reste comme frais de labour et de sarclage. Ces  intrants seront achetés au grand marché de Sikasso. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues au grand marché de la même ville en détail (souvent en gros) à divers clients. 
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 45.000 à 80 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The ten members of the Jekadi D group in Kapala are all married women and live in large traditional households. They are, on average, 33 years and have at least 4 children. Kapala is part of the outer ring of Sikasso (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali).
The group members all farm tiger nuts.
With the goal of making their farming activity more profitable, the group members joined Soro Yiriwaso's loan program two years ago. Chatou, one of the group members, intends to use her loan to buy 1 bag of urea and 2 bags of complex cereals, and to use the rest to pay for labour and hoeing costs. These agricultural inputs will be bought at the grand market in Sikasso. After the rainy season, the harvest will be stored for a certain while so that the crops will be worth more when sold at the grand market in Sikasso at retail (often in bulk) to various customers.
Chatou foresees realizing an average profit of 45,000 to 80,000 FCFA, which will be used to pay the interest on the loan and to provide for her family's ongoing needs.

loans.use: To buy agricultural inputs and to pay for labour costs.

loans.name: Kambeng Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité est créé le 19 octobre 2001. Il est constitué de six femmes qui habitent le même quartier. Leur activité principale est le petit commerce.

Madame Fanseyni qui est à la droite de la photo levant la main est responsable de groupe. Elle est âgée de 46 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de cinq enfants. Elle a aussi en sa charge trois autre enfants confié par ses proches.

Elle s’active dans la vente de produits maraichères. Elle a une bonne expérience dans ce domaine d’activité

Ce prêt lui permettra de renforcer son capital et de mieux développer  ses activités.

Les profits lui permettront d’améliorer les conditions de vie de la famille (santé, nourriture, habillement etc.…) et d’augmenter ses épargnes.
texts.en:
This solidarity group was created on 19 October 2001. It comprises six women who live in the same area. Their main activity consists of small retail businesses.

Ms. Fanseyni, on the right with the raised hand in the photo, is responsible for the group. She is 46 years old, married, and has five children. She also takes care of three additional children entrusted to her by close relations.

She is active in selling market garden products. She has lots of experience in this field.

This loan will allow her to strengthen her capital and further develop her business.

Her profits will allow her to improve her family's standard of living (in terms of health, food, clothing, etc.) and to increase her savings.

loans.use: To buy market garden products.

loans.name: Drocella

texts.en:
Drocella is 30 years old and is married with four children between the ages 3 and 10 years old. Her business is well-organized and she sells beans in her business. Drocella employees two people to help her and she has four years of experience.

Drocella has requested a loan from Kiva lenders in order to purchase more beans to sell. With these profits, Drocella will reinvest in her business and pay her children's school fees.

loans.use: to purchase more beans to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 41-year-old married man and the father of four children. Three of the children are still attending school. He is from Lebanon. He is an experienced furniture carpenter and has owned a carpentry shop since 1995. He makes original furniture designs and modern ones. He works upon the request of his clients. He is the main income provider of the family. Today, he is requesting to borrow $1,000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase tools and supplies for his work. He estimates that the upcoming results will be prosperous and successful thanks to the loan.

loans.use: to purchase tools and supplies

loans.name: Inayat's Group

texts.en:
Inayata, 55, is the leader of this group. She resides in the southern town of Tashkomur, which has a small population. She often noticed a lack of good cafes and small restaurants for residents to go out and eat various meals at accessible prices. Inayat therefore decided to combine her cooking and management skills and open a small café. Quickly, thanks to a small advertisement, her café became one of the most visited. Her husband, a retiree, and her son help with the café management in their free time. A monthly revenue of 20,000 soms helps to make major repairs and build additional rooms. Inayat would like to also build a summer café. For this purpose, she is asking for a Kiva loan. Inayat’s wish for the future is the construction of a small shop by the café. 

         --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to build a summer cafe.

loans.name: Jean Marie Vianney

texts.en:
Jean is 33 years old and married, with four children between the ages of 3 and 11 years old and six dependent relatives. Jean has five years of experience selling Irish potatoes. His business is well organized and he employs one person.

Jean has requested a loan from Kiva lenders in order to buy large quantities of Irish potatoes. Jean will use the profits generated from this loan to reinvest in his business and to pay his children's school fees.

loans.use: to buy large quantities of Irish potatoes.

loans.name: Obidon

texts.fr: Agée de 31ans, Mme est revendeuse de boissons depuis 2006. Son conjoint est commerçant et ils ont  01 enfant en charge. Elle est une ancienne cliente de WAGES et est à son quatrième prêt. Ce montant qu’elle sollicite lui servira à s’approvisionner en boissons pour répondre à la demande de ses clients.  L’achat se fait à la brasserie de Lomé et elle revend dans son bar nommé « BAR FOMBI »
texts.en: At 31 years of age, this lady has been retailing beverages since 2006. Her spouse is a merchant and they have one dependent child. She is a long-standing WAGES customer and this is her fourth loan. She will use the amount she is requesting to procure beverage supplies to meet her clients' needs. She purchases from Lomé brewery and resells in her bar named "Bar Fombi."

loans.use: to purchase beverages.

loans.name: Tattygul's Group

texts.en:
Tattygul, 24, is the leader of this group. Despite being younger than the other members, she expressed a wish to lead the group. Tattygul is the young mother of two children, the oldest being three. Five years ago, following her husband’s initiative, she purchased her first livestock for 15,000 soms. She took good care of them, feeding and watering them, before further reselling in a farm yard. Her parents try to help her run the business, along with taking care of her children. The monthly income reaches 10,000 soms. Tattygul has applied for a loan from Kiva to buy more livestock. She thanks all Kiva lenders for this significant help.

         --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase livestock.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 24-year-old single woman from Lebanon. She is living with one parent and three siblings. She has been working as a farmer for the past five years. In 2008, she started to work on her own land planting vegetables. She has hired a part-time employee to help her with the farming work. Today, she is requesting to borrow $800 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase agriculturA. spices and seeds in order to improve her business productivity. She intends to increase her sales and earn a higher income to be able to better support her family.

loans.use: to purchase agricultural spices and seeds

loans.name: Sereebaatar

texts.en:
Mr.Sereebaatar, 37, is divorced and lives with his 11 year old son, his mother and his younger brother and sister in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. They live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent in the ger district of the city. 

Since 2000, Sereebaatar has been running a transportation business using his family minivan. He has permission to carry passengers on one of the city’s remote bus lanes which lacks bus services. In his family he is the only bread winner. His younger brother works casually at a construction site as a laborer.

Sereebaatar is planning to buy a small family car and to use it as a taxi. His younger brother has a driving license and he wants his brother to drive the taxi to generate extra income for the family. The loan Sereebaatar is taking will be used to buy this car.

loans.use: to buy a small car for his younger brother to use as a taxi.

loans.name: Dancille

texts.en:
Dancille is 28 years old and married, with three children between the ages of 2 and 5 years old. She has five years experience selling local drinks.

Dancille has requested a loan from Kiva lenders in order to expand her business by buying a large quantity of local drinks. Dancille will use the profit generated from this loan to save for her future and to reinvest in her business.

loans.use: To purchase a large quantity of local drinks.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 51-year-old married man living with his wife and two children. He is from Lebanon. He is the main income provider for his family. He has more than 30 years of experience working as a farmer. He has been running his own farm since 1990. He cultivates all types of vegetables. His goods are sold to multiple vegetable shops. Today, he is requesting to borrow $1,200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase spices and seeds needed for his agricultural work.  He is confident that the loan will help him improve his business.

loans.use: to purchase spices and seeds

loans.name: Battsetseg

texts.en: Battsetseg, 49, is a widow living with her three sons in a house in the Baganuur district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She manages a grocery trading business in her town, which she began six months ago. Even within this short period of time, she has been able to manage her store successfully. She is a polite woman who is planning to expand her business. She says, "I want to increase my business sales." She is requesting a 600,000 MNT loan to purchase more goods for her store.

loans.use: to purchase more goods for her store.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 51-year-old widowed mother of one child. She is from Lebanon. She has been running a clothing store since 2009. She sells different types of clothes and always presents the new collections to her customers in order to satisfy their demands. Despite her age, she works hard in cooperation with her son to be able to pay the family expenses. Today, she is requesting to borrow $1,000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to expand her store’s inventory. She says that the loan will help her diversify her merchandise selection. In the future, she is hoping to sell shoes also in her store.

loans.use: to expand her store’s inventory

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase additional products

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase hair products and other cosmetics for her beauty salon.

loans.name: Munhbayar

texts.en: Munhbayar is 41 years old and lives with her husband and three children in a ger, a Mongolian yurt, in the Baganuur district of Ulaanbaatar city. Her older two children, age 11 and 16, go to a local secondary school and the younger one, age 6, is in kindergarten. She manages a clothing trading business in a rented stall at a trading center. She started her business in 2003 and is planning to expand it in the future. Now she sells all kinds of clothes for all ages. She has been able to stabilize her business and build a strong customer base. She is a polite woman who says, "All I want is to educate my children and help them to have better jobs." She is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase shoes for her business.

loans.use: To purchase shoes to sell

loans.name: Marthe

texts.en:
Marthe is 50 years old and married, with five children aged between 3 and 7 years old. She has three years experience in her business selling Irish potatoes. Her business is well-organized.

Marthe has requested a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to purchase more Irish potatoes to sell. Marthe will use the profit generated from this loan to reinvest in her business and save for her five children.

loans.use: To purchase more Irish potatoes to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is an 18-year-old single man from Lebanon. He is living with his parents and four siblings. He started his career at a very young age, working as a plumber. His work is specialized in installing toilets, faucets etc. He works on a freelance basis sticking with multiple projects and private businesses. Today, he is requesting to borrow $1,200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase additional materials for his work such as pipes, bathroom fixtures, etc. He says that these purchases will allow him to better serve his clients.  In the future, he is willing to expand his business operation into wider areas.

loans.use: to purchase pipes, bathroom fixtures, etc for his plumbing business

loans.name: Chuluunbaatar

texts.en: Chuluunbaatar is 44 years old and lives with his wife and son in a ger, a Mongolian yurt, in the Uvs province of Mongolia. His son is 14 years old and attends a local secondary school. He manages a meat and meat product trading business with the help of his wife. They started their business at a local market in 2007 and are planning to expand their business. They collect husbandry animals from herders and sell their meat to city residents. He is a friendly man who says, "I want my son to be educated and have a better job." He is requesting a 650,000 MNT loan to purchase husbandry animals for his business.

loans.use: To purchase husbandry animals

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more materials needed for his work

loans.name: Philomene

texts.en:
Philomene is 41 years old and married, with five children between the ages of 4 and 14 years old. Philomene has one year's experience in her business selling various goods such as beer and Fanta. Her business is well organized and she currently employs one person to help her.

Philomene has requested a loan from Kiva lenders through Vision Finance Company in order to increase her business by buying a large quantity of beer and Fanta. Philomene will use the profit generated from this loan to improve her business and save for her future.

loans.use: to buy large quantities of beer and soft drinks

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 25-year-old engaged woman from Lebanon. She lives with her parents and one sibling. She has been working for several years as a beautician. In 2010, she opened her own beauty salon where she started to offer her customers different beauty services. Her business income is very important, because she is planning to get married soon and needs to gather enough money to be able to afford the wedding expenses. 

Today, she is requesting to borrow $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase additional beauty products. In the future, she is planning to expand her business level.

loans.use: to purchase additional materials for beauty care.

loans.name: Ammar

texts.en:
Ammar, 56, is a married construction worker specialized in cement making and building. He works hard to do everything in his projects, including building, blending cement and making the cement covering. Ammar is requesting his third loan from Al Majmoua in order to buy raw materials needed to make his cement blend.

Ammar is an honest and good standing borrower who works hard to please his customers. He is a hard worker and seeks perfection in his business. He  hopes to expand his work and widen the region in which he sells cement.

loans.use: to buy raw materials for his business.

loans.name: Jekadi F Group

texts.fr:
JEKADI F  est un regroupement de 9 femmes du village de KAPALA. Les femmes vivent chez leurs mariées dans des grandes familles traditionnelles. Elles sont âgées d’au moins 29 ans et possèdent en moyenne  2 enfants. Situé à environ 17 km de Sikasso troisième région administrative de la république du Mali, le village de Kapala est aujourd’hui érigé  en un chef lieu de commune de la préfecture de Sikasso. 
Les membres du groupe exercent comme toutes les femmes du village la culture du pois sucré, ce produit est très consommé actuellement par des industriels de la région qui font sa transformation en jus et son exportation. 
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs activité agricoles, les membres du groupe ont donc décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso il y’a maintenant deux ans. ROKIA compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence de pois, des intrants et des équipements appropriés pour sa production et sa récolte. Ces équipements et intrants seront achetés au grand marché de Sikasso. A la suite des récoltes en fin de campagne, les produits sont stockés pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendus  au grand marché de la même ville en détail (souvent en gros) à divers client.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 85.000 à 130 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille. 
NB: MINATA était absente lors de la prise des photos pour raisons de santé.
texts.en:
The “Jekadi F”  group consists of nine women from the village of Kapala. The women live together with their husbands in traditional extended families. They average at least 29 years of age with two children. The village of Kapala, located about 17 km [10.5 miles] from the city of Sikasso, the third administrative region of Mali, has become a county seat in the Sikasso Prefecture.

The group members, like other women in the village, cultivate sweet peas, much in demand by local manufacturers for juice production and export.
With the goal of making their agricultural work profitable, two years ago the group members decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso credit program. Rokia plans to use her goal to buy a sufficient quanity of sweet pea seeds, agricultural inputs and necessary tools for  farming and harvesting. The tools and inputs are bought at the big market of Sikasso. After harvesting at the end of the agricultural cycle, the produce is stored until its value has increased sufficiently to allow it to be sold at the big market of the same town, retail (often wholesale) to a diverse customer base.
Rokia plans to achieve a monthly income between 85,000 and 130,000 West African Francs, which will be used to repay the interest on her loan and cover everyday family expenses. 

NB: Minata was absent for health reason when this photo was taken.

loans.use: to buy sweet pea seeds, agricultural inputs and  tools

loans.name: Jekadi  E Group

texts.fr:
Les 10 femmes du groupe JEKADI E font partie de l’association JEKADI I de KAPALA. Elles sont toutes mariées et vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 33 ans, au moins 4 enfants. Le village fait partie de  SIKASSO troisième  région administrative de la république du Mali.  
Elles exercent la culture du pois sucré, un produit très convoité actuellement par des industriels de la région qui font sa transformation en jus et son exportation. 
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs activité agricoles, les membres du groupe ont donc décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso il y’a maintenant deux ans.
FATOUMATA  compte  utiliser  son prêt pour acheter  1 sac d’urée, 2 sacs de complexe et le reste comme frais de labour et de sarclage  Ces intrants seront achetés au grand marché de Sikasso. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues au grand marché de la même ville en détail (souvent en gros) à divers client.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 35.000 à 45 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The 10 women  of the “Jekadi E” group belong to the Jekadi 1 association of Kapala. They are all married and live in traditional expanded families. They average 33 years of age, with at least four children. Their village is in Sikasso, third administrative region of Mali.

They cultivate sweet pea, a product very sought after by the local manufacturers, who turn it into juice and export it.
