The couple lives in a village along National Road Number Two, about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have one son and two daughters. One is a garment factory worker and the other two are in school.  

She is asking for a loan of US $500 to help with her pig farming by enabling her to purchase additional pigs and feed for pigs.

loans.use: To purchase additional pigs and feed for her pigs.

loans.name: Sainkhuu

texts.en:
Sainkhuu is 31 years old. He lives with his wife and parents-in-law in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. He and his wife are a newly wed couple and currently they don’t have their own house. 

Sainkhuu has been running a farming business since 1996 by growing vegetables such as carrots, potatoes, cabbages and onions. He is an experienced farmer. 

He used to rent a van to deliver his products to the market, but recently, he bought a minivan. Now he uses his minivan to transport his own vegetables to market and he transports other farmers' vegetables to market as well. 

The loan he is taking will be partly used to invest in his farming business and partly to build a garage for his minivan.

loans.use: To invest in his farming business by extending his land plot and also to build a garage for his minivan.

loans.name: Seam

texts.en:
Seam is 40 yeas old. She is a widow with two sons and two daughters. Two of her children are garment factory workers, one is construction worker and another is in school. The family lives in a village along National Road Number One, about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. 

Seam sells snacks in the local school. 

She is asking for a loan of $1,000 to buy a motorcycle for her son, who is a construction worker, to drive to work.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle for her son to drive to work.

loans.name: Van

texts.en: Mrs. Van is a 61-year-old farmer and mother from the Prey Chor district of Kompong Cham province. She was blessed with four children, two of whom are employed in various jobs. Her husband, Gnim, is 52 and works in the farming business. Mrs. Van and her husband grow different kinds of crops on the farmland she inherited from her grandmother. Mrs. Van will be using her loan to buy a secondhand motorcycle for her children to ride to work so that they can decrease their traveling expenses. Mrs. Van and her husband are pictured under their house.

loans.use: to buy a secondhand motorcycle for her children to ride to work

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional grocery items for her inventory.

loans.name: Ry

texts.en: Ry, 38, is a villager living in a rural area of Siem Reap province. She is married with three single children, one of whom works in the construction field. Ry is a construction foreman, earning an income of around US $4 each day to use for the family’s needs. To help provide more food for the family, her husband is also employed as a construction leader. Ry is requesting a loan to buy some piglets for breeding and more planks to repair her old house.

loans.use: to buy some piglets for breeding and more planks to repair her old house.

loans.name: Candida Rosa

texts.es:
Cándida , es originaria del departamento de León , tiene 49 años de edad , es viuda, tiene 4 hijos todos son mayores, ella es dueña de una pulpería , es comerciante . Inicio en esta actividad por herencia, ya que la dueña de la venta era su abuelita  después paso a manos de su madre y ahora la tiene ella. Antes de  hacerse cargo de la venta doña Cándida  era asistente de odontología, ella tenía 19 años, trabajaba en mecánica dental haciendo calzas de dientes. Pero pasado el tiempo se hizo cargo por completo de la pulpería  así ha venido abriéndose camino en el comercio  sin dejar atrás el trabajo de mecánica dental  combinando estos dos trabajos, les dio una carrera universitaria a casi todos sus hijos pues le faltan dos de sus hijos para que finalicen su carrera. La pulpería la tiene en su casa de habitación su hija menor es la que le ayuda a atender la venta. 
Solicito el crédito para surtir la venta  y comprar material dental. Espera que esta inversión le ayude a mejorar sus ventas y aumentar sus ingresos. Tiene como meta próxima comprar dos exhibidores nuevos para colocar productos, también vitrinas nuevas ya que las que tiene están muy viejas y en mal estado, desea convertir su pulpería en una distribuidora.
texts.en:
Cándida is from the department of León.  She's forty-nine, a widow, and has four grown children.  She is a storekeeper and owns a general store.  She inherited the store; her grandmother owned it, then it passed to her mother, and now it's hers.  Before taking over the store Cándida was a dental assistant.  At nineteen she was working in a dental practice doing fillings.  After a while she took over the store completely and that's how she got to be a storekeeper, but she hasn't left the dental office, so she's got the two jobs.  She provided college educations to nearly all of her children; two of them are still finishing school.  She has the store in her house and her youngest daughter helps her operate it.

Cándida is seeking a loan to stock up the store and to buy dental supplies.  She hopes the investment will help her improve sales and grow her income.  Her next goal is to buy two new display cases to put her products in, as well as new windows since the ones she has are old and in bad shape. She would like to make her store a distribution center.

loans.use: to stock up her store, and buy dental supplies.

loans.name: Annaliezl

texts.en:
Annaliezl is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a ready-to-wear clothes business in the Philippines. 

Annaliezl has been in this business for two years. She earns additional income from food vending.

Annaliezl has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF

She is borrowing PHP 12,000 through NWTF to purchase more stock to sell for her ready-to-wear clothes business.

She dreams of saving enough money to expand her business and to send her children to school in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more stock to sell.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Khoem

texts.en: Mrs. Khoem, 61, is a low-income person who has been working in the farming business for many years in the province of Kompong Cham. She is married to 69-year-old Mr. Chea, who used to work as a primary teacher in his village. The couple is blessed with two children who have been working in different careers to earn profit. The family's house is getting old and really needs repair but the family currently doesn't have enough savings to do so. Mrs. Khoem is asking for a Kiva loan to repair her old house.

loans.use: to repair her old house.

loans.name: Elvira

texts.en:
Elvira is 42 years old and married with five children, two of whom attend school. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. For the past two years, Elvira has run a general store in the Philippines.

Elvira is requesting a 10,000 PHP loan through NWTF to purchase more stock to sell in her store. In the future, Elvira would like to save enough money to be able to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase more stock to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Marie Chrisbie

texts.en: Marie Chrisbie is 36 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is separated with four children. Marie Chrisbie has a food shop that sells different flavors of pizzas & serves coffee. She has had this business for five years. She requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy raw ingredients like flour, eggs & food seasonings. Marie Chrisbie is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Marie Chrisbie hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy raw ingredients like flour, eggs & food seasonings

loans.name: Alma

texts.en: Alma is 48 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married. Alma has a food shop that sells pizza pies. She has had this business for five years. She requested a loan for PHP 5,000 to buy raw ingredients like flour, eggs, meat, sausages & food seasonings. Alma is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Alma hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy raw ingredients like flour, eggs, meat, sausages & food seasonings

loans.name: Bernandita

texts.en:
Bernandita is 43 years old and married with a child. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. For the past 10 years, Bernandita has run a fruit and vegetable business in the Philippines. 

Bernandita is requesting a 10,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy additional stocks of vegetables and fruit to sell. In the future,she would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy fruits and vegetables to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Conchita

texts.en: Conchita is 53 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married. Conchita has a retail shop that sells several kinds of clothing like t-shirts & blouses. She has had this business for five years. She requested a loan for PHP 5,000 to buy stocks of clothing from NATASHA & AVON. Conchita is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Conchita hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy clothing from NATASHA & AVON for her store

loans.name: Jazzille Don

texts.en: Jazzille Don is 20 years old and lives in the Philippines. He is single. Jazzille Don is working in an eatery as a service crew member and will use the loan to provide for his daily needs. He had been working for two years. He requested a loan for PHP 5,000 to buy his daily personal needs like food & clothing. Jazzille Don is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Jazzille Don hopes to improve his business.

loans.use: to buy his daily needs like food & clothing

loans.name: Munkhbaatar

texts.en:
Mr. Munkhbaatar is 35 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. They live in their own small family house which was built a few years ago. Munkhbaatar’s three kids attend a local secondary school. His wife rents a small cafeteria in a crowded area of the city and runs it successfully. Munkhbaatar runs a taxi business using his family car to bring extra income to the family. He also delivers goods to his wife’s cafeteria before it opens. 

Munkhbaatar is planning to build an extension to his house and is requesting a loan to buy necessary building materials. He will add an extra room for his kids because his family is growing and at the moment space is very tight.

loans.use: to buy building materials to add an extension to his house

loans.name: Naseem's Group

texts.en:
Naseem is a 42-year-old seamstress, who sews clothes for her neighboring clients to fulfill the needs of her family. She has four children and all of them are enrolled in a local school and getting their education. 

Her husband operates a Punjabi food restaurant. He is very skillful in making Punjabi food and Naseem also helps him in preparing food. She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the further expansion of her husband’s business. With the loan, he will buy required ingredients such as spices, cooking oil, etc. for making food in larger quantity to be able to sell more and increase the profits. 

He has been operating this business for the past 25 years and Naseem is confident that an investment will help him grow his business further and increase his profits.

loans.use: To buy required ingredients for Punjabi food business.

loans.name: Kyzylgul's Group

texts.en:
Kyzylgul is 49 and is married to a famer. Together with her husband, she has raised three sons, all of whom are also farmers. In 1991, when the Soviet Union broke up, the family got a piece of land and since then they have earned money by cultivating agricultural products and breeding livestock. 

Kyzylgul is the leader of this loan group. She applied for the loan because she needs additional funds to purchase more livestock. With money gained from reselling her livestock, Kyzylgul wants to improve her family’s living conditions. In the future, she wants to save money to purchase a vehicle for her older son so that he will be able to work as a taxi driver.


--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – people (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase livestock

loans.name: Maksat's Group

texts.en:
Maksat is a member of this group.  She is 36 and married to a private entrepreneur. Together with her husband she brings up two daughters and two sons. All the children except the youngest daughter study at school. Thirteen years ago Maksat sold a potato harvest and with the initial investment of 30000 soms she opened her own shop. She sells clothes and grocery goods; at the moment her monthly profit is 10000 soms. With the profits gained from the trade Maksat purchased a truck and a house in Bishkek. She applied for the loan because she needs some additional financial funds to increase the commodity turnover in the shop. She wants to purchase soap detergents, foodstuffs and summer clothes. In the future Maksat plans to start building a second floor in the shop.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase soap detergents, foodstuffs and summer clothes

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a fishing business in the Philippines. 

Elizabeth has been in this business for 12 years. She earns additional income from manicure/pedicure services and weaving.

Elizabeth has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF

She is borrowing PHP 20,000 through NWTF to buy fishing net and other equipment for her fishing business.

She dreams of saving enough money so she can afford to send her children to college in the future.

loans.use: to buy fishing net and other equipment for fishing.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Sajidakan's Group

texts.en:
Sajidakan, 51, is the leader of this group. Her husband works in Russia and each month he sends 5,000 KGS to his family to meet their needs.  

Sajidakan has three children. The older daughter is married and lives separately with her family and the other children study at school. 

In order to earn money to support the family budget, Sajidakan cultivates vegetables and cotton. She has been doing it for 15 years. This business helped her to contribute money for celebrating her daughter’s wedding. 

Sajidajan applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase mineral fertilizers for cultivating cotton. In the future, she wants to provide her children a good education and plans to start building a fence around the house.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line: people (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase mineral fertilizers.

loans.name: Olmahon's Group

texts.en:
Olmahon is the leader of this group. She is 45 and married to a driver. Her husband owns a truck; he provides transportation services and earns 9,000 KGS per month. Together they are bringing up a daughter and a son; both of them are at school.  

In order to meet the family needs, Olmahon cultivates cotton. She has been doing it for 18 years. With money received from the loan, she wants to purchase mineral fertilizers for cultivating cotton and tires for the truck. 

In the future, Olmahon wants to give her children a good education.


--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line: people (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase mineral fertilizers and tires for the truck.

loans.name: Poeng

texts.en:
Poeng, 46, is a rice farmer who resides in Kompong Chhnang Province. On average, she can earn about $1.75 each day from her farming business. 

She is a married mother who is blessed with three children who study in public school. 

Her husband helps support the family by selling palm leaves. He sells his items to people who need to weave palm leaves into furniture and roofing material. 

In order to make additional income, Poeng requested a loan for her husband to buy additional palm leaves to stock up for resale.

loans.use: to buy additional palm leaves to stock up for resale.

loans.name: Ainura's Group

texts.en:
Ainura, 29, is the leader of this group. She resides in Karabalta, a small town near to Bishkek (the capital of Kyrgyzstan). 

Her husband went to work in Russia to make money. Ainura takes care of two daughters. Both of them are at school. 

In order to meet the family's needs, Ainura sells children's clothes at the market. At the moment, her business is running well and she decided to apply for the loan in order to increase the commodity turnover. With money received from the loan, she wants to purchase more clothes for trade. 

In the future, Ainura wants to purchase a vehicle and improve the family’s living conditions.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line: people (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase children's clothes.

loans.name: Nam

texts.en: Nam  is 40 years old, married, and has two children. She lives in Le Xa village, Mai Hien commune, Dong Anh district. She and her husband are farmers. Her family has a monthly income of 4,000,000 Vietnamdong (VND). She has participated in SEDA since 2009 and repaid her loans punctually. In this loan cycle, she is requesting a loan for  8,502,000 VND to invest in livestock.

loans.use: to invest in livestock.

loans.name: Bazarbu

texts.en:
Bazarbu, 53, is a resident of Tashkomur – a small mining town in southern Kyrgyzstan. Unfortunately she is a widow. Since 1991, she has made a living by selling vegetables and various other products people use in their homes. Her son helps her run her business, and they earn a monthly profit is 11,000 soms. This profit has made it possible for Bazarbu to build her own store. She is applying for this loan to buy more items to sell to her customers. In the future, Bazarbu would like to expand her business to provide better support to her family. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to buy vegetables for resale

loans.name: Le Xa 1-8 Group

texts.en:
Hoa is 48 years old,married, and has two children. She lives in Le Xa village, Mai Hien commune, Dong Anh district, Ha Noi city. She is a farmer and her husband is a businessman. She grows rice nad raises pigs for meat.They have a monthly income of about 7,000,000 Vietnamdong (VND). She is requesting a loan for 5,014,000 VND to invest to buy food for pigs. She is the leader of a six-member group in SEDA.

Chien is 52 years old. She is requesting a loan for 5,014,000 VND to buy pigs.

Suot is 47 years old. She sells brooms in the market. She s requesting a loan for 7,194,000 VND to small business.
 
Cai is 22 years old. She sells fruits in the market. She s requesting a loan for 5,014,000 VND to invest in her fruit shop.
 
Ut is 31 years old. She sells vegetables in the market. She s requesting a loan for 7,194,000 VND to small business.
 
Van is 49 years old. She s requesting a loan for  7,630,000 VND to invest in her shop.

loans.use: to invest to buy food for pigs

loans.name: Liezle

texts.en: Liezle is 32 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married. Liezle has a retail shop that sells canned goods, snacks, biscuits & beverages. She has had this business for five years. She requested a loan for PHP 5,000 to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages. Liezle is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Liezle hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages

loans.name: Zamira

texts.en:
Zamira is 43 years old, married, and has two children, one of whom attends school.  She is a resident of Tashkomur – a small mining town in the south of Kyrgyzstan. Seven years ago with an initial investment of 6,000 soms, Zamira started to sell groceries. She sells rice, oil, macaroni, soda, etc. She earns 12,500 soms per month. In seven years Zamira increased the commodity turnover up to 35,000 soms. With money received from the loan, she wants to purchase more rice, oil, and macaroni. In the future, Zamira wishes to expand her business and give her children a good education.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly,) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visi: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase rice, oil, and macaroni.

loans.name: Luz

texts.en: Luz is 57 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with one child. Luz has a computer game shop that provides computer facilities, especially games. She has had this business for five years. She requested a loan for PHP 5,000 to pay for the utilities and maintenance of the computers. Luz is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Luz hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to pay for the utilities and maintenance of her computers

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en:
Arlene is 50 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with five children. Arlene has a retail shop that sells canned goods, snacks, biscuits & beverages. She has had this business for 10 years. She requested a loan for PHP 5,000 to buy additional stocks of canned goods & snacks.

Arlene is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Arlene hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy additional canned goods & snacks to sell

loans.name: Safia's Group

texts.en:
Safia is a 53-year-old caring lady. She stays at home and carries out her responsibilities as a housewife very well. She makes the utmost effort to provide comfort to her family by fulfilling their needs. 

Her husband deals in scrap. He has good number of business contacts which give him regular orders every month. Safia has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband who wants to buy scrap such as plastic bottles, used papers, etc. to be able to fulfill larger orders on time and increase his profits. He has five years of experience in his business and Safia is hopeful that an investment will bring great profits to him which will help her family to enjoy better facilities of life. 

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 3rd loan application. In previous loan years, she has maintained a good credit behavior and never missed any meeting. 

Note: In the photo, the lady raising her hand is Safia.

loans.use: To buy scrap.

loans.name: Marife

texts.en:
Marife is 33 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with three children. Marife has a retail shop that sells beauty products like lotions, shampoo & face powder. She has had this business for five years. She requested a loan for PHP 5,000 to buy additional stocks of beauty products from NATASHA & AVON.

Marife is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Marife hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy additional beauty products from NATASHA & AVON

loans.name: Shergazy

texts.en:
Shergazy lives in the town of Tashkomur. He is 53 years old and married. His wife helps support the family by running a store where she sells rice and honey. Shergazy works as a taxi driver and also breeds cattle. He went into these lines of work 25 years ago with an initial investment of 2,000 soms. Today he earns 5,000 soms per month and is applying for this loan to buy more cattle to raise. He believes that this loan will help him to reach his goals of expanding his business and improving his family's living conditions. 

-- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to buy more cattle.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is 44 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with three children. Josephine has a retail shop that sells medicinal coffee and generic medicines. She has had this business for five years. She requested a loan for PHP 5,000 to buy additional stocks of medicinal products like coffee.

Josephine is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Josephine hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy additional medicinal coffee and generic medicines

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en: Mary Jane is 39 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with two children. Mary Jane is providing manicure & pedicure services. She has had this business for 15 years. She requested a loan for PHP 5,000 to buy utilities for the maintenance of the service. Mary Jane is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Mary Jane hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional nail polish and nail enhancer.

loans.name: Minda

texts.en: Minda is 50 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with one child. Minda has a retail shop that sells canned goods, snacks, biscuits & beverages. She has had this business for 10 years. She requested a loan for PHP 5,000 to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages. Minda is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Minda hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages to sell

loans.name: Jeleta

texts.en: Jeleta is 55 years old, widowed, and has nine children, one of whom attends school.  She is in the agricultural business raising livestock in the Philippines. Jeleta is requesting a loan for 16,000 PHP through NWTF to buy additional livestock.  She has been raising livestock for two years and has borrowed 15 times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.  In the future, Jeleta would like to repair and renovate her family home.

loans.use: to buy additional livestock

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en: As a married parent with nine children, Josephine works hard to support her family. She makes a living by using bamboo leaves to make nipa, an item used in roofs in Philippines. She also runs a sari-sari (or variety) store. Josephine is applying for a loan for PHP 11,000 from NWTF to buy additional items for her sari-sari (variety) store and to buy more bamboo leaves to use in her nipa-making business. She has already received and repaid four loans from NWTF member, and is committed to earn and save enough money to provide her family with a secure financial future.

loans.use: to buy a bamboo leaves and items to sell in her variety store.

loans.name: Perlita

texts.en:
Perlita is 63 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with four children.Perlita has a retail shop that sells canned goods, spices, oils & vegetables. She has had this business for five years. She requested a loan for PHP 5,000 to buy additional canned goods, snacks, vegetables & spices.

Perlita is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Perlita hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy additional canned goods, snacks, vegetables & spices to sell

loans.name: Mercedita

texts.en:
Mercedita is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a food vending business in the Philippines.  She is requesting a loan for 10,000 PHP through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food business.  Mercedita has been in this business for two years and earns additional income from sari-sari (variety) store.

Mercedita has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF.  She dreams of expanding her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food business

loans.name: Adiya

texts.en: Adiya is 65 year old, widowed, and has one adult child. They live in a ger, a Mongolian yurt, in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She manages a shoe-making business with the help of her daughter. They started their business in 2003 and gained much experience. Adiya is responsible for making children's shoes and her daughter is responsible for making adults' shoes. They sell their products at a rented stall at a Narantuul market, one of the busiest markets in Ulaanbaatar city. Their products are well-known among their customers for quality and durability. Adiya is a diligent woman who attributes her business success to her good accounting skills. She says, "I want to earn much money by increasing my business sales." She is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan to purchase shoe materials for her business.

loans.use: To purchase shoe materials.

loans.name: Batnairamdal

texts.en: Mr. Batnairamdal is 27 years old and lives with his wife and daughter in Kherlen, a city in eastern Mongolia which is about 750 kilometers away from the capital. Since 2005, Batnairamdal has made a living by driving a taxi and is currently his family's sole means of support. His wife is a student and will graduate this summer as an accountant. Their daughter is one year old. Batnairamdal uses his family car in his taxi business but the car is old and needs to be replaced. He plans to sell it and buy a new one, and is applying for a loan to get the additional money he needs to pay for the new car.

loans.use: to buy a new and better taxi.

loans.name: Dolgorsuren

texts.en:
Dolgorsuren is 28 years old and lives with her daughter in a ger, or Mongolian yurt, in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia's capital. Her daughter, who is six years old, goes to kindergarten while Dolgorsuren runs a consumer-goods business at a rented stall at Narantuul, one of the busiest markets in Ulaanbaatar.

Dolgorsuren started her business in 2005 and now sells more than 200,000 MNT worth of goods every day. She has also begun importing products from China, and says, "Previously I used to buy my products from wholesalers in Mongolia. However, I began importing my goods directly from China, and it is much more profitable than before."

Dolgorsuren uses her profits to care for her daughter and buy the many things she needs in life. She is an open-minded woman who says, "I am working hard to save money to build a house." She is applying for a loan of 2,500,000 MNT to buy construction materials for this new house.

loans.use: to buy construction supplies to build a house.

loans.name: Kasawo Youth Brick Layers Group

texts.en:
26-year-old Ivan is strong on conviction that he will carve out an even stronger niche for his brick sales business once he acquires this loan. Ivan plies his business in Kayunga, where currently many people from various parts of the country are relocating due to the  area's fertile soils. It is therefore fair to say there is in a way a construction boom which has been going on in the area. Though Ivan has been in this business for only two years, he says his involvement in this business is already paying dividends. 

Out of his weekly brick sales he is able to make profits totalling Ugandan shillings 185,000. For a business that is just in its fledgling years, this is good indication that future success is feasible. Ivan is envisaging better prospects for his business in the next five years. His plans are for expansion. This business he says was begun with savings from his farming business. With this loan he says he is going to purchase better brick-making machines and more firewood to burn the bricks.

loans.use: To purchase a brick-making machine and more firewood.

loans.name: Epifania

texts.en:
Epifania is married with six children. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. Epifania is 48 years old and has two children who are in school.

Epifania buys and sells natural (herbal) medicines in the Philippines. Epifania requested a PHP 15,000 loan amount through NWTF to purchase more stock to sell.

Epifania has been in this business for five years.  In the future, Epifania would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase more stock to sell.

loans.name: Riimaa

texts.en:
Mrs. Riimaa is a 46-year-old divorcee. She lives with her four children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She has been running a clothes retail business for 12 years. She has stall at the Kharkhorin, the second largest outdoor market in Ulaanbaatar city. 

Twelve years ago she started up her business with 80 USDs as starting capital and now her working capital has reached 2400 USDs. Recently she has added one more stall at the market to increase her sales and profit. Her three daughters help in her business. 

Last year she started a family house building project and it is not completed yet. The exterior is nearly finished and the interior decoration needs to be done. She is planning to move in  before September 2011. The loan Riimaa is taking will be used to buy necessary building materials such as a cement, sand, gypsum boards, plaster, paint and wallpaper and to complete the interior decoration of the house.

loans.use: To buy necessary building materials such as a cement, sand, gypsum boards, etc.

loans.name: Charlotte

texts.en: Charlotte is 30 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with four children. Charlotte has a retail shop that sells used clothing or ukay-ukay. She has had this business for five years. She requested a loan for PHP 5,000 to buy a bundle of used clothing. Charlotte is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Charlotte hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy a bundle of used clothing

loans.name: Leonida

texts.en:
Leonida is married with two adult children. She earns about Php 3,000 per month raising pigs.

Leonida raises pigs so that she can have a source of income. With her diligence she earns a minimum of PHP 3,500 whenever she sells one of her raised pigs. To sustain the daily feed needed by her pigs, Leonida is asking for a loan to buy piglets that she can sell in the future. 

In the future, Leonida hopes that her piggery will further improve so that she can provide for the needs of her family.

loans.use: to buy piglets that she can raise and sell in the future.

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn is 45 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is widowed. Marilyn has a beauty parlor that provides hair cutting, styling, pedicures & manicures. She has had this business for 10 years. She requested a loan for PHP 5,000 to buy materials & tools needed for the beauty parlor.
Marilyn is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Marilyn hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy materials & tools needed for her beauty parlor

loans.name: Inkanyezi Group

texts.en:
Zanele is 30 years old and single with two children who are seven and 11 years old; both of them attend attend school. For a year she has run a retail business selling Green World products from door to door in Kwa Zulu Natal of Empangeni, South Africa. She also receives income from the government's child grant program. In the photo she is pictured raising her hand.


Zanele is requesting this loan through WDB and Kiva to buy kids' clothes for resale. She says that customers who take her products on credit and fail to pay on time are her main business challenge. The extra income arising from this loan will help her business grow, enable her to better support her family, and save for their studies at a higher institution.

loans.use: to buy kids' clothes for resale.

loans.name: Nd 1-1 Group

texts.en:
Thom is 57 years old with 3 children. One of them is studying at Financial and accounting University.  She has been a client of our credit program since 2004 and has accessed seven loan cycles — the last one for 5,014,000 Vietnamese dong. All loans were used to invested in expanding her  vegetable shop. Being the leader of a four-member group, she is responsible for punctual repayment. For her new loan size cycle, she is requesting a loan of 8,066,000 Vietnamese dong to improve her shop conditions and buy products to meet the demand of customers.

Thoa is 55 years old with three children. She has a butcher shop in a local market. She needs a loan of 8,066,000 Vietnamese dong to invest in her shop
 
Van is 53 years old with two children. She manages a shop that sells fresh vegetables. She needs a loan of 6,322,000 Vietnamese dong to improve her shop.

Huong is 42 years old with two children. She grows rice and vegetables, and raises chickens. She needs a loan of 7,194,000 Vietnamese dong to buy fertilizer and pesticide.

loans.use: to improve her shop conditions and buy products to meet the demand of customers

loans.name: Munkhbold

texts.en: Mr. Munkhbold is 38 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His son attends a secondary school and his daughter goes to kindergarten. Munkhbold’s wife works as a chef at Trauma Center Hospital. Munkhbold has been running a taxi business since 2009, using his family car. A few years ago he bought a plot of land with a old, small house on it. Munkhbold is planning to restore the house and to fix the fences around it. The loan Munkhbold is taking will be used to buy wood planks for fences, roof tiles and to pay for labor costs.

loans.use: To buy wood planks to fix his fences and new tiles to replace his roof tiles and to pay for labor cost

loans.name: Jazgul

texts.en:
Jazgul, 21, lives in Tashkomur. She is married to a farmer and they have a new-born baby. In order to earn money the family cultivates agricultural products and sells them on the market. They started this activity four years ago with an initial investment of 10,000 soms. At the moment the monthly profit is about 20,000 soms. With the profits the young couple celebrated their wedding and purchased bedroom furniture. With money received from this loan, Jazgul wants to purchase mineral fertilizers and seeds for farming. In the future she dreams to build a big house for the family.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase mineral fertilizers and seeds for farming

loans.name: Bakyala Tukulakulane Group

texts.en: Hawa, 35, is the happily married mother of six. She has more than 20 years experience in running her food sales business at a stall in Kayunga Market. She cites diligence, determination, and persistence as factors that have been pivotal in her day-to-day operations. The fact that she also owns a farm comes in really handy in that she is able to sell foods from it in the event of shortages. Her business is quite lucrative given the fact that people purchase food every day. There are, however, some seasons when food prices rise and crop sales fall. This means a plummeting in profits. Hawa principally sells fresh fruits and vegetables. She however also sells foods she grows on her farm like bananas, cassava, maize and beans. Weekly, her sales profits total shillings 180,000 and she says with this Kiva loan, she is going to purchase more fresh fruit like pineapples, pawpaws, mangoes, oranges and jack fruit to sell.

loans.use: To purchase fresh fruit like pineapples, pawpaws, mangoes, and oranges to sell

loans.name: Aurea

texts.en:
Aurea is 49 years old and married. To earn a living she raises pigs. She has operated this business for five years. Although the business is quite tiring, she does not mind at all because she wants to assist her husband support their needs, especially the education of their children.

To continuously manage her business, Aurea is requesting a loan of Php15,000 to buy piglets to raise and sell in the future. With additional piglets she is positive that she can earn a higher income.

loans.use: to buy piglets to raise

loans.name: Hope Alive Group

texts.en:
This is 47-year-old Rosemary (pictured in the middle of the photo) from the town of Mutare in Zimbabwe. She is a widowed pensioner with three children aged nine, twelve and fifteen. Two of the children attend school.

Rosemary sells clothing and shoes and employs one person. She has been in business for three years and says the main challenge she faces is the high prices of the goods she sells.

Rosemary has requested a loan of $400 to boost her stock. She says the extra income generated as a result of this loan will allow her to send her children to better schools. In the future Rosemary plans to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy more clothes and shoes to sell.

loans.name: Batma's Group

texts.en:
Batma is 46 and divorced. She has raised a son and daughter. The son is engaged in retail trade, and the daughter works in Russia. She is the leader of this three-person group.

Two years ago with an initial investment of 20,000 KGS and her son’s help, Batma started to sell fruits and vegetables. In this way the family has come to earn 5,000 KGS per month. With the profits gained from this business the family has started to build a house.

Batma has applied for a loan because she needs additional funds to purchase more fruits and vegetables. In the future she plans to finish the construction of their house and open her own grocery store. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase more fruits and vegetables for resale.

loans.name: Blandino

texts.en:
Blandino is 58 years old and lives in the Philippines. He is widowed with three children. Blandino has a shop that sells copra (dried meat) from coconuts. He has had this business for five years. He requested a loan for PHP 5,000 to buy additional coconuts for copra.

Blandino is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Blandino hopes to improve his business.

loans.use: to buy additional coconuts for copra

loans.name: Rissa

texts.en:
Rissa  is 18 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is single. Rissa has a retail shop that sells electronic loads from several networks. She has had this business for a year. She requested a loan for PHP 5,000 to buy additional electronic loads from several networks like SMART & GLOBE.

Rissa  is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Rissa  hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy additional electronic loads from several networks like SMART & GLOBE

loans.name: Aida

texts.en:
Aida 49 years old and married. She has a retail shop where she sells different products to her community. She has been in business for three years.

Aida is requesting a loan of 15,000 PHP to buy more products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods and condiments. She believes that with perseverance and this loan she can achieve her dream of enlarging her store.

loans.use: to buy more products for her store.

loans.name: Arceli

texts.en:
Arceli is 46 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is widowed with one child. Arceli has a retail shop that sells RTW or ready to wear clothing like t-shirts, underwear & blouses. She has had this business for five years. She requested a loan for PHP 5,000 to buy more stock of t-shirts & blouses.
Arceli is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Arceli hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy more t-shirts & blouses to sell

loans.name: Purevsuren

texts.en:
Purevsuren is 63 years old and lives with her husband and two children in their own house in a suburb of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia.

Purevsuren is a photographer, and she works in Sukhbaatar Square, the central square of the capital, Ulaanbaatar. Lots of people who come from abroad and the far reaches of the province go to Sukhbaatar Square where Purevsuren may take their photo in memory of their visit. Purevsuren’s son and daughter both have learned her profession and become photographers as well.

The house where Purevsuren’s family lives has gotten old and needs renovation. The loan Purevsuren is taking will be used to put an extra layer of brick wall around the house to make it warmer, replace roof tiles and doors, and decorate the house’s interior.

loans.use: to renovate her house.

loans.name: Camila

texts.en: Camila is 49 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with two children. Camila has a retail shop that sells clothing like t-shirts & blouses. She has had this business for five years. She requested a loan for PHP 5,000 to buy more products from NATASHA & AVON.  Camila is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Camila hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy more products from NATASHA & AVON

loans.name: Cresila

texts.en:
Cresila is 44 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with one child. Cresila has a retail shop that sells canned goods, junk foods, biscuits, beverages & detergents. She has had this business for 10 years. She requested a loan for PHP 5,000 to buy additional canned goods, junk foods & beverages.

Cresila is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Cresila hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy additional canned goods, junk foods & beverages

loans.name: Raima

texts.en:
Raima is a divorced woman with two children. She is a hardworking woman who heads the family’s business of sewing the country’s traditional dress. She has been in production for more than five years. Raima purchases the materials needed for her sewing from Khujand region.

Raima has many customers, and was able with her profits to celebrate the weddings of her children. Raima would now like to get a loan of 6,000 TJS to purchase materials needed for her business. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy sewing materials.

loans.name: Flordeliza

texts.en:
As a widowed mother of five children, Flordeliza works hard to support her family.

She has a food production business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from selling clothing and herbal medicines. Flordeliza is seeking to borrow 14,000 PHP ($325) through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food production business.

Flordeliza has been fortunate enough to finance her business activities in recent years through six prior loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money to send her children to college.

loans.use: To purchase additional ingredients for her food production business

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:
Stephen is a 34-year-old, married man with three children.

To earn a living, he works in the welding industry. He has been in this line of work for 11 years. He works with seven employees in his business. In addition to his welding work, he farms sugarcane to supplement his income.

Through Faulu Kenya, he has learned how to manage his finances and to save for his family's future wants and needs. He hopes to build his own business so that he can save on rental fees. He is requesting a loan in the amount of 60,000 KES ($700) to buy a water tank because he would like to start a water sales business.

loans.use: To start a water sales business by purchasing a water tank

loans.name: Delia

texts.en:
As a married mother of six children, Delia works hard to support her family.

She has a business where she sells fruits and vegetables in the Philippines, and she earns additional income by selling various items at a general store. Delia is seeking to borrow 10,000 PHP ($250) through NWTF to buy more fruits and vegetables for re-sale purposes.

Delia has been fortunate enough to finance her business activities as of late through a prior loan from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money to send her children to college.

loans.use: To purchase additional fruits and vegetables.

loans.name: Kombassé Edith

texts.fr:
Mme Edith est une femme mariée. Elle a 3 enfants. Le plus âgé à 8 ans et le moins âgé à 1 an.2 vont à l’école et elle ne prend personne en charge.

L’activité principale de Mme est le mercure : c’est-à-dire vente de tissus et accessoires de mercerie. Elle exerce ce métier depuis 3 ans. Mme s’approvisionne au grand marché de ouagadougou.Ses clients sont ses voisins du quartier et surtout les couturiers.

Elle veut s’acheter 5 roulots de tissus, un paquet de bouton, un paquet de billet de coton, un carton d’huile de machine un demi paquet  de fermeture et un demi-canton de fils à coudre.

Elle veut utiliser ses bénéfices pour agrandir son activité. Mme ambitionne devenir une grande commerçante de tissus et accessoires de couture. Elle veut s’occuper de ses enfants et assurer le bien être de sa famille.
texts.en:
Mme Edith is a married woman. She has three children. The oldest is eight and the youngest one year old. Two go to school, and she is not responsible for anyone else. 

This lady's main business is selling lengths of cloth and sewing notions. She has been doing this work for three years. She buys her supplies at the big open-air market of Ouagadougou. Her customers are neighbors in her area and especially dressmakers.  

She wants to buy five bolts of cloth, a packet of buttons, a pack of cotton balls, a carton of machine oil, half a packet of zippers, and half a box of thread. 

She wants to use her profit to expand her little business. She would like to become a big cloth merchant selling sewing accessories. She wants to take care of her children and ensure the well-being of her family.

loans.use: to buy cloth and sewing notions.

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en: Elsa, a 55-year-old married mother of seven children,  earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines, an enterprise she has had for three years. She earns additional income from selling vegetables. Elsa, who is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream of saving enough money to be able to send her children to college, is requesting a loan of PHP 19,000 through NWTF to buy feeds and additional piglets.

loans.use: to buy feeds and additional piglets.

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en: Erlinda, who is married and has a fruit and vegetable vending business in the Philippines, works hard to support her family. In business for three years now, she is requesting a PHP 10000 loan through NWTF to buy additional stocks of fruits and vegetables to sell. In the future, Erlinda would like to save money to expand her business and send her children to school.

loans.use: to buy additional stocks of fruits and vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en:
Rosita, 46, is a married and has 11 children, five of whom are in school. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. 

Rosita has a candle-making business in the Philippines. Rosita requested a 15,000 Philippine peso (PHP) loan through NWTF to purchase wax, muds and other materials for candle making. 

Rosita has been in this business for three years. In the future, Rosita would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase wax, muds and other materials for candle making

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Florencia

texts.en:
Florencia is 52 years old, married, and has three children. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. 

Florencia has a fruits and vegetables vending business in the Philippines. She requested a 10,000 Philippine peso (PHP) loan through NWTF to buy additional fruits and vegetables to sell in her stall. 

Florencia has been in this business for 20 years. In the future, Florencia would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: To buy additional fruits and vegetables to sell in her stall

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy cereals and a bundle of wood.

loans.name: Francisca

texts.en:
Francisca works hard to support her family. She is married and has a fruits and vegetable vending business in the Philippines. 

Francisca requested a 10,000 Philippine peso (PHP) loan through NWTF to purchase additional stocks of fruits and vegetables to sell. 

Francisca has been in this business for 30 years now. 

In the future, Francisca would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of fruits and vegetables to sell

loans.name: Maribel

texts.en:
To generate income for her family--especially for her two school-aged children--Maribel opted to engage in a livestock business. She raises pigs for sale. She usually earns 3,500 Philippine pesos (PHP) when she sells one of her grown pigs. 

Aiming to earn higher income, Maribel decided to request loan of 15,000 PHP to buy vitamins and livestock feed. She believes that with sufficient feed her pigs will grow healthier and heavier.

loans.use: to buy vitamins and livestock feed

loans.name: Alicia

texts.en:
Alicia is married and has three children. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. Alicia is 48 years old and has one child who is in school. 

Alicia has a sari-sari (variety) store business in the Philippines. Alicia requested a 20,000 Philippine peso (PHP) loan through NWTF to buy more stock for her store. 

Alicia has been in this business for five years. In the future, Alicia would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: buy more stock for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Akouvi

texts.fr: Mme Akouvi a 30ans. Elle est revendeuse de produits de premières nécessités (riz, sucre, huile végétale), des pagnes et bazins. Son conjoint est tailleur et ils ont un enfant en charge. Elle est dans cette activité depuis 2007 et s’y plait beaucoup. Elle est à son premier prêt et cet argent lui permettra d’acheter des marchandises pour mieux relancer son activité. Elle s’approvisionne à Lomé et fait la vente à toutes personnes dans sa maison.
texts.en: Mme Akouvi is 30. She buys and sells staple goods (rice, sugar, vegetable oil), lengths of African print cloth and damask cloth. Her husband is a tailor and they are raising one child. She has been in this business since 2007 and it really suits her. She is on her first loan, and this money will permit her to buy merchandise to get her little business going better. She buys her supplies in Lomé and sells out of her house to all comers.

loans.use: to buy staple goods, lengths of African print cloth, and lengths of damask.

loans.name: Douglas

texts.en:
Douglas is 33 years old, married and blessed with a five-year-old child who goes to school.   He runs his business in the Githurai area in Nairobi, capital city of Kenya.  He has been in the business of supplying stationery for five years.  

Douglas also works as a freelance researcher to generate extra income.  He appreciates Faulu Kenya because he has grown his business hence improving his financial status.  He has requested 60,000 Kes to expand his business by adding more stationery.

In the future, he hopes to expand his business further and become a successful businessman.

loans.use: To buy more stationery.

loans.name: Laili

texts.en:
Laili is a hard-working woman. She is a divorced woman and the mother of three children. Her family lives in Kanibadam, Tajikistan. She is engaged in selling foods and manufactured products.  She has received 18 loans from Imon International  and from the profit she opened a store in “Kuchkak” village of Kanibadam city. She has been in this business for ten years. 

Laili is hoping to take out a loan of 4000 TJS for the expansion of her business so she can keep her business running successfully. This purchase will enable her to increase her sales and to earn more money. 


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy food products and household goods.

loans.name: Komivi Semeko

texts.fr: Marié à une revendeuse, Komivi a 30ans. Il a crée une boutique « ETS SELOM BENEDICTION » depuis 2008 dans laquelle il vend des produits de premières nécessités (riz, sucre, huile végétale), et des produits congelés. Elle sollicite ce premier crédit pour répondre à la  demande croissante. Son approvisionnement se fait au Grand marché de Lomé et il revend dans sa boutique.
texts.en: Married to a wife who also sells small items, Komivi is 30. In 2008, he opened a little shop called « ETS SELOM BENEDICTION » where he sells staple goods (rice, sugar, vegetable oil) and frozen foods. He is requesting this first ever loan to respond to growing demand. He buys his supplies at the Grand market in Lomé and he resells them in his shop.

loans.use: to buy staple goods.

loans.name: Muhabbat's Group

texts.en:
Muhabbat is the leader of this group. She is 44 and married to a farmer. Together with her husband she has raised three sons and two daughters. The first son works in construction; two younger children study at school and the others grow clover to earn money.  The family is also engaged in cattle breeding.  

Muhabbat sells dairy products to earn additional money. In this way she earns an additional 2500 soms per month.  With money received from the loan she wants to purchase more cattle for breeding. In the near future, Muhabbat plans to start repairing their house.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase cattle.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is 42 years old. She is married and has two children, neither of whom are currently in school. Rose has a business selling timber, which she has had for five years. She also has a second business providing rental houses.
To help expand her business, Rose has requested a loan of 1,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more timber for resale. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Rose hopes to generate greater profits and buy food for her family. In the future, she hopes to expand her business further.

loans.use: to purchase more timber for resale.

loans.name: Shinebayar

texts.en:
Mr. Shinebayar is 23 years old and lives with his wife and one-year-old baby in Kherlen, a city in the far-eastern province of Mongolia. They live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, which is temporarily built on Shinebayar’s friend’s plot of land. His wife is a teacher but currently she is looking after the baby. 

Shinebayar served in the Mongolian Army on two years' contract which was finished last year. After the Army service he wed his wife and started a family life. He has a dream: to have his own family home in the future. 

Shinebayar runs a taxi business using his family car and the car needs some proper service now. The loan Shinebayar is asking for will be used to buy necessary spare parts and to service his car which is only source of his family’s income at the moment.

loans.use: To buy necessary spare parts and to service his car.

loans.name: Kayraba Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité est créé le 19 octobre 2001. Il est composé de sept femmes qui habitent le même quartier. Leur activité principale est le petit commerce.

Madame Aissatou (à la droite de la photo levant la main) est responsable de groupe. Elle est âgée de 40 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de six enfants.

Elle fait la vente de légumes et de l'huile de palme. Elle pratique cette activité depuis plusieurs années

Ce prêt lui permettra de renforcer son capital et de mieux développer  ses activités.

Les profits lui permettront d’améliorer les conditions de vie de la famille (santé, nourriture, habillement etc.…) et d’augmenter ses épargnes.
texts.en:
This solidarity group was formed on October 19, 2001. It is made up of seven women who live in the same neighborhood. Their principal business is buying and selling various small items. 

Madame Aissatou (on the right in the photo, raising her hand) is the leader of the group. She is 40, married, and the mother of six children. She sells vegetables and palm oil. She has been in this business for several years. 

This loan will permit her to expand her capital and develop her business further. The profit will let her improve living conditions for her family (health, nutrition, clothing, etc.) and put aside more in savings.

loans.use: to buy palm oil and vegetables.

loans.name: Titus

texts.en:
Titus, a 37-year-old, is married and has two children aged 5 and 8.  He runs a retail shop so as to earn a living for his family.  He also earns additional income because he is employed in a salon.  

Titus has been operating his business for ten years.  He was able to expand his business with his first loan from Faulu Kenya.  Besides, he has gained business management skills from the training sessions conducted by Faulu Kenya.  His dream is to build his own house and own a car.  He has requested 50,000 Kes to buy sugar, maize flour, soap and toothpaste for his general store.

loans.use: To buy sugar, maize flour, soap and toothpaste.

loans.name: Touba Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité est créé le 17 aout 2005. Il est composé de 11 femmes qui viennent de la même localité. Elle font comme activités la vente de l'huile de palme, du piment et du pain de singe.

Madame Fang (à la droite de la photo levant la main) est responsable du groupe. Elle est âgée de 45 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de cinq enfants. Elle a aussi un enfant en sa charge confié par un parent proche.

Elle s'active dans la vente du piment qu'elle produit dans son jardin. Elle a une très bonne expérience dans ce domaine. Elle pratique cette activité depuis plusieurs années.

Ce prêt lui permettra d'augmenter sa capacité de production en achetant des semences de qualité et des intrants afin de mieux développer son activité.

les profits qui seront tirer de cette opération lui permettront de renforcer ses épargnes et de participer à l'amélioration des conditions de vie de la famille(santé, habillement, nourriture etc.)
texts.en:
This solidarity group was created on August 17, 2005.  It is made up of 11 women who live in the same area.  For work, they sell palm oil, hot peppers, and fruits of the Baobab tree.  Madame Fang (at the right of the photo, raising her hand) manages the group.  She is 45 years old.  She is married and the mother of five children.  She also cares for the child of a nearby relative.

She sells hot peppers which she cultivates in her garden.  She has great experience in this area, as she has carried out this work for many years.  This loan will allow her to increase her production capacities by purchasing quality seeds and agricultural inputs in order to better develop her business.  The profits made from this operation will allow her to grow her savings and to better the livelihoods of her family (health, clothing, diet, etc.)

loans.use: to purchase palm oil and pepper seeds.

loans.name: Koutediomboulo Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité est créé le 19 octobre 2001. Ledit groupe est  composé de quatre femmes qui habitent le même quartier. Leur activité principale est le petit commerce.

Madame Fatou (à droite de la photo levant la main) est responsable de groupe. Elle est âgée de 36 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de quatre enfants. Elle a aussi en sa charge un autre enfant confié par un parent.

Elle s’active dans la vente d'arachide et d'huile de palme. Elle a une bonne expérience dans ce domaine d’activité, pour l'avoir pratiquée depuis plusieurs années.

Ce prêt lui permettra de renforcer son capital et de mieux développer  ses activités.
Les profits lui permettront de participer à l'amélioration les conditions de vie de la famille (santé, nourriture, habillement etc.…) et d’augmenter ses épargnes.
texts.en:
This solidarity group was established on October 19, 2001.  The group is made up of four women who live in the same neighborhood.  Their main business is petty trading. Madame Fatou (to the right of the photo, raising her hand) manages the group.  She is 36 years old.  She is married and the mother of four children.  She also looks after the child of a relative.  Her business is primarily that of selling groundnuts and palm oil.  She has great experience in the business, having worked in this domain for many years.  

This loan will allow her to grow her capital stock and better develop her business.  The profits will allow her to contribute to improving the livelihoods of her family (health, diet, clothing, etc...) and to grow her savings.

loans.use: to purchase groundnuts and palm oil.

loans.name: Benedicto

texts.en:
Benedicto is 26 years old, married and has one child, who is not currently in school. He has a small retail shop, which he has run for two years.
To help expand his business, Benedicto has requested a loan of 1,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more essential commodities, such as sugar, for resale. With the help of his loan from BRAC, Benedicto hopes to generate greater profits and buy food and basic necessities for his family. In the future, he hopes to expand his business further.

loans.use: to purchase more essential commodities, such as sugar, for resale.

loans.name: Koutediomboulo Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité est créé le 17 aout 2005. les 09 femmes qui composent ce groupe habitent toutes le même quartier.

Madame Sire Demba qui est à droite de la photo levant la main est le responsable du groupe. Elle est âgée de 40 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de trois enfants.

Elle s'active dans la vente de sucre, de savon, de poisson sec et de l'huile de palme. Elle a une très bonne expérience dans ce domaine, pour l'avoir pratiquer depuis plusieurs années.

Ce prêt lui permettra de développer ses activités en renforçant son approvisionnement en marchandise.

Les bénéfices lui permettront d'augmenter ses épargnes et contribuer à l'amélioration des conditions de vie de la famille(nourriture, habillement)...etc
texts.en:
This solidarity group was created August 17, 2005. The nine women who compose the group all live in the same neighborhood.

Mrs. Sire Demba, who is on the right of the picture with her hand raised, is the group's leader. She is 40 years old. She is married and a mother of three.

She is active retailing sugar, soap, dried fish and palm oil. She has a very good experience in this domain, since she has been operating in it for several years.

This loan will make it possible for her to expand her activities by strengthening her stock of merchandise.

Profits will allow her to increase her savings and to contribute to the improvement of the family's living conditions (food, clothing, etc.)

loans.use: to buy sugar, soap, dried fish and palm oil.

loans.name: Sabougnima Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité est créé le 28 juin 2002. Les 10 femmes qui composent ce groupe habitent toutes le même quartier et mènent le petit commerce comme activité.

Madame Awa qui est à la droite de la photo levant la main est responsable du groupe. Elle est âgée 69 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de six enfant. Elle a aussi un enfant en sa charge confié par un voisin.
